description:
Amazing hole in the wall,food is amazing!! 
sad that it doesn't get a lot of costumers!definitely would recommend it to others. 
I'll be back for sure!!

**Negative part is a tip if forced on you didn't really like that
author: Marla M.

description: I found glass in my chicken cashew and all the manager said was sorry very disappointed and I hope the glass I ate isn't going to cut my insides up the waiter wanted her tip and they didn't seem very concerned about me
author: Steve C.

description: I will never come back. Called ahead they said they close at 9:30 we were shoot out the door practically yelled at with repeated "NO's!" At 9:10 what a joke
author: Ronnie S.

description:
We ordered the steam whole fish and chose the tilapia (over the black bass and catfish they also had), a vegetable of stir fried Snow Pea tips with Garlic and steamed rice.  With this order came house soup, oranges and tea. 
 This evening, we were served Lotus Root soup, which was very good. 

The steam tilapia was steamed to perfection before being covered with sweet soy sauce, ginger, scallions and cilantro; it, too, was very good.   

The sautéed snow pea tips' stalks were crisp and hollow and the leaves, tender and flavorful.

The dining room was a bit tired, the bath room was small (think jet liner size) but the food was very good, the prices were extremely reasonable and the service was friendly and helpful.  Hard to beat.
author: Frank L.

description: One of the few really good old-school restaurants left in the City, New Woey Loy does classic Chinese/American food right.   Spicy Orange Chicken, Fish with Blackbean, Sweet & Sour Pork, Mongolian Beef, all outstanding.   For a taste of San Francisco's Chinatown back when it had the best cuisine on the west coast and plenty of family-owned atmosphere, you can't go wrong with this little gem.
author: David M.

description:
I ordered Chicken with Black Mushroom and Rice ($5.95) from the lunch menu even though it was dinner time. My friend was able to order a dish that wasn't specifically on the menu but was a combination of two dishes. He also got charged only $5.95 for his dish.

The food quality was average. I liked how big the mushroom slices were though. There were also carrots and celery in my dish.
The chairs were a little bit sticky.

We did have to wait a while to make an order and to get our dishes.

It was nice seeing an actual receipt. At many of the other Asian restaurants that I have been to, I may be given a piece of paper that just lists numbers or not receive a receipt at all. 

There is a minimum $20 credit card charge. 

In general, this place has great value! The tea was free. The food was really cheap.The portion sizes were big. I could not finish my dish and ended up bringing the rest home.
author: Kristina M.

description: This place has been in the city, literally, forever! The food is authentic and great tasting. Your not going to get the "fast-food," mass produced, prepared faire here. All orders are made to order and to your liking. No request is too much.
author: Carlos B.

description: Cheapest place in SF Chinatown. Foods are so good. Tasty with lots of wok ha. Their beef and tofu, tomato beef chow mein and three treasures rice plate is good. Recommended. Not that clean but good.
author: Allen L.

description:
New Woey Loy Goey is a casual Chinese restaurant located within a basement area in San Francisco's wonderful Chinatown!

They've got all your typical Chinese dishes, but the one thing I really enjoy the most here is their pan fried pork cakes with salty fish. Traditionally, the "pork cakes" are very wet and moist, but for a dollar extra, you can ask them to pan fry it. The end result is quite the opposite, being more firm and dry. With salty fish mixed in or salty egg, the pork cakes go extremely well with white rice. Add in some vegetables, fried fish, spare ribs, etc. for an excellent meal with friends and family!
author: Joshua M.

description:
Great food, fantastic price. Must try this when in Chinatown. Highly recommended.

The best option is the family style. It is super flavorful and authentic (for my taste).
author: Angel V.

description: Great value for comfort Chinese food! There's A  LOT of options for rice plate which range from $7-10 including complimentary soup of the day. Favorites include oxtail and spicy claypot eggplant. The 2 ladies who work there are also super sweet, offering refills on my soup, extra rice, and taking initiative to wrap up our leftovers.
author: Eric M.

description:
i choose you pikachu... err, New Woey Loy Goey [SF Chinatown]

If you are familiar with Pokémon it is an expression used by Ash when choosing to use his favorite pokemon, pikachu, in a battle. Except our battle was choosing where to eat in Chinatown as there was a superabundance of restaurants to choose from and almost all of them packed with hungry diners and some overflowing out the door.

We found this place very close to where we just came from at the Golden Gate Bakery. We crossed the street, went inside and down a few steps and we were in the heart of the restaurant... no lobby, no waiting area, no hostess reception desk, no host/hostess! There was a small cashier table to the left and a long counter right next to it. This was where people waited to be seated including us and we were seeing people being served, people eating, everything right in front of us while waiting. A round table opened up that seated 8 but there were only me and hubby and a young family of 3 ahead of us. We shared the table with them and it all worked out. Our wait time was only 10 minutes.

Looked through the menu and the prices were very reasonable. I decided on the Mongolian Beef rice plate (not spicy). It took awhile for my meal to come maybe because I chose  to not have it hot plus the restaurant was super busy. When it finally arrived i savored and enjoyed each bite, the meat was tender, authentic and very flavorful. It included sautéed onions, green onions and slices of green pepper. Hubby had the Short Ribs in Black Pepper with rice and he enjoyed his meal as well. 

People were still coming in as we were leaving. Locals seem to love this place. When I searched Yelp for "best Chinese restaurants in Chinatown" this restaurant came in at #45. Good food, good prices! We'll be back although I'd like to try the other restaurants here in Chinatown :)

Review #0632 (and 221st review for the business)
author: May A.

description: Very fast service. Ordered some drinks and a meal. Drinks were at the table within 2 minutes and food within 10. Very authentic feel, a lot of locals eating here. Recommend to anyone in china town. Fast and good meal
author: Noel A.

description:
This review is for February 2018.  

FOOD:
The food was good, but the service was not.  4/5 stars for the food.  

 - Peking Pork Spareribs $8.95 - 5/5
The spareribs were deep deep fried just right and mixed with a red sweet and sour sauce.

 - Half a Chicken with Ginger & Scallions - $9.95 - 5/5
This chicken is very tasty but it doesn't have a lot of meat.  In Chinese, it's pronounced "Wong Mo Gai".

 - Steamed Pork Hash with Salted Fish $9.50 - 5/5
This is steamed ground pork with a couple of cut pieces of salted fish.  Very good.   
 
 - Sauteed Mustard Greens with garlic $7.50 - 5/5
Fresh and tender.

 - Salt & Pepper Shrimp $9.95 - 3/5
Good flavor but it was hard to remove the shells.  

 - Chicken Fried Rice $6.50. -5/5  Good flavor.

 - Chinese Broccoli with Beef $9.95 - 5/5
Broccoli cooked just right, but for some people, they might prefer it to be softer.   

Sorry, only took a photo of the Chicken Fried Rice.  Forgot to take photos of the rest of the food.  Too hungry.  

SERVICE:
The older male server was and is very RUDE.  He yelled at us for not ordering enough food.  How rude for him yelling and giving us an attitude!   Dining here before, he was always rude.  Would prefer to dine here when he's not working that day.  

Go for the food, but not for the service.
author: J W.

description: While I was on vacation with the family in San Francisco, we stopped in a Tourist shop to pick up a few items and we asked the gentleman there where he suggested we should eat. He said we should go to oh we goey wee woo wee. Apparently this is where locals like to go eat when in Chinatown. You step down the stairs into this restaurant. We showed up around 1:30 so the place is completely empty and that was awesome. Our crowd was large so we sat at a large round table and we received great service immediately. It seem like no one really spoke English and that was great. Our food was brought to us quickly. We had tea first and then the rest of the items came out. I can't remember what we ate, but it was very special and everyone enjoyed it.
author: Cinna B.

description:
Packed with Chinese folks - so it's got to be good! Large portions, great value and quick service. For those that think service isn't good - this is just how it is in Chinatown anywhere. 

Great sweet and sour soup, duck rice, oysters and chicken rice. Don't order the lemon chicken - super deep fried.
author: Bailey A.

description: Our yearly trip to the coast wouldn't be complete if we didn't stop here. The food is fresh and delicious. Always great service down to them packing the food that I couldn't finish. Love seeing all the locals come in and the tourists that just happen to stumble in like we did three years ago.  This place.
author: Sonya A.

description: The duck is fantastic!! Roasted and Peking is superb! The food came out fast and delicious!!
author: Agnes M.

description: Loved it! Great sidestep from Grant and 5 min from Columbus. Bbq egg foo young and king pao chicken delicious!
author: Edward A.

description:
Great food and reasonable price in San Francisco! All the times I've gone for dinner, little to no wait. I've gone with a group of 6, no problem. 

Favorites:
-sizzling rice soup
-fried rice
-Mongolian beef
author: Joyce P.

description:
Inexpensive and large portions.
Friendly staff.
Very authentic.
author: Jess P.

description:
Great little place for a quick dinner. They have Chinese family menu available. I ordered typical fish with Chinese black bean sauce  rice plate . I had to ask for pork chow mein in Chinese for hubby. Not usually available after lunch.
It's very busy after5:30, Asian families will roll in.You will get soup along with your meal. (free)Noisy. 
You have to climb down to this place.No elevator available. Go early or you will not get in.
author: Sandie S.

description:
Food: 4/5       Price:5/5       Service:3/5       Ambience:1/5

Super cheap, authentic, small restaurant in China Town that serves pretty great food. I have to say the lunch special is incredibly cheap and you really cannot complain. They even give the table a free soup of the day. Great extensive menu, ranging from rice plates, meat/seafood dishes, noodle soup, wonton.... Perfect place for a quick simple lunch.  

Favorites:
* 鼓汁三寶飯 ($4.95) - black bean sauce combination plate, with eggplants/ tofu/ green pepper stuffed meat
* 例湯 - soup of the day

Others:
* 椒鹽鮮魷 ($8.50) - spicy salt and pepper squid
* 大燴飯 ($5.95) - Special rice, with squid/ pork/ shrimp/ mushroom/ vege
* 蝦球雲吞 ($6.50) - prawns won ton soup
author: Victoria L.

description: We like this restaurant. My wife wanted to go for mother day. It was pack with Chinese families celebrating there mothers. We didn't have a reservation, but we only have to wait few minutes as they invited us to share the big table with another family. the food was fenomenal. We had the chinese roasted duck, The orange chicken, and the Mongolian beef. All delicious, Generous portions and great prices !!!
author: Gregory G.

description: Cheap, tasty, amazing variety. Come check out this staple of Taishanese home cooking. The rice plates are huge. I'd like to bring enough people to tackle an entire cooked fish. If you like offal as much as I did, you're in luck! Tongue, stomach, meats, seafood. Ask for the free soup to start if they forget to bring it out. All the staff is really friendly.
author: Alejandro R.

description: Authentic food, service is great and food is great!  This is the place to go if you are looking for real authentic Chinese food, if you want something more American then I would say order from the standard American menu. If you are want to be a little adventurous try their fish, orange peel beef or their squid perfectly cooked!
author: Annie Y.

description: I tried the Kung Pao Chicken dish and it was very tasty with flavor.  This place was recommended to me and it was great. Great prices too!
author: Derek Y.

description: i give this one 5 stars because this is the best restaurant i  ever had! coke drink is good tea are good and the food was delicious!
author: Tony C.

description: The food was absolutely delicious!! We came back and ordered duck the second time. Let me just say it was one of the best Iv ever had! I Will definitely be coming back when I'm in San Francisco.
author: Daphne F.

description: The deep fried founder is to die for. Absolutely amazing and mouth watering. Just pair it with the veggies and add a couple of rice and viola, you are like at home being served by a chef! The ambiance is just right though people tend to talk loud but when you are really hungry, you really don't mind the noise.
author: Bev B.

description: Came to China town with family from London & Mexico & we started walking around. Saw this place FULL OF PEOPLE I MEAN FULL. So I knew the food was gonna be good! They seated us quickly, waitress came right away we ordered our food & omg it was sooooo good!!! I've never been to China so I don't know what authentic food really tastes like but I feel like this would be it! LOL food was bomb.com!!! Couldn't get enough of it defenely coming back!
author: Thania H.

description:
2nd time to New Woey Loy Goey Restaurant we had a late lunch after 1pm and place was busy.

I wanted wonton hofun noodles, but lady kept asking if I wanted meat.  What?  ok meat bbq pork.  So I got noodles and bbq pork, but no wontons!  Aiya.  Since it was written in Chinese can't tell if I paid for the wontons in the soup, cheap anyways under $7.

B. got wonton beef stew noodles - under $7, he liked his dish.

Mixed vegetable dish - not enough veggies, they put tofu, snow peas, mushrooms, and vermicelli noodles!  Under $7.

Can charge it, but we again paid Cash!  Aiya, gotta remember to ask if we can use Cards.

I gotta stick to my oxtail and rice dish which I liked last time!
author: Ann L.

description: One of the lesser known restaurants in Chinatown serving excellent Chinese food at extremely competitive price. Three of us had a barramundi stir fried fillets and the ''bones' cooked with Tofu and bean sauce. Pork cooked with dried shrimp past. Stir fried egg plant and tofu stuffed with pork. Together with soup, rice and desert came to less than US$60/-!
author: Meng L.

description:
Short version: some dishes are amazing, others are lackluster, but it's all around rather authentic if you're chasing that sorta thing in Chinatown. We were directed here by a local shopkeeper whom we asked where a great place to eat was. She said all the locals go here. 

The orange peel beef is amazing... slightly spicy, tangy as all get out, good level of sweetness, and crispy. Oh so wonderfully crispy (like: how do they do that?). 5/5

The Mongolian beef was... not what most Westerners would expect (not sweet at all). It was tender meat with some sautéed onions and green peppers, but no real strong flavors. 2/5

To be honest, we got potstickers as well to fill our bellies, which were awesome and crispy but not served with any sauce except the soy sauce and hot sauce on your table. 4/5 (because they were delicious even just with soy)

Tea at the table: 2/5. I love tea, and I'm accustomed to a certain level of tea in the Chinese restaurants out in Atlanta on Buford Highway. This tea... made me sad, but at least it was something to drink on a cold day with a warm meal. 

Service was polite (ehhhh well mostly) but rather mixed. Example: they start out by bringing you a pot of hot tea and some cups (sweet!) but then proceed to literally scoff/laugh at you when you order water with your meal (even though some nearby tables have water?) (and they never bring you water, so you secretly sip from your hidden bottled water if you really need some). However, while they initially bring you forks to eat with, they will then oblige if you ask for chopsticks instead. I understand some places don't like to offer water because it's a cultural thing in several countries to just have tea. But if families from those same countries are right next to you drinking glasses of water... let's just say I get confused.
author: Haviland F.

description: I have been coming here since I moved to SF and Its always consistent and fresh, made to order and love my meals here. I get the Mongolian Beef over rice usually and its one of the best in town. Thank you for your service over the years!
author: Robert N.

description: Good food. But really really bad service took forever to be seated and to order. They demand and yell at you to give them more tips than whatever you want to give them she snatched the money from my hand and laughed then showed off the money to the other workers while laughing. They have no manners at all and it seems like they only do this to some people. I saw a lot of people leaving way less in tips than me and nothing was said to them
author: Caroline R.

description: They demanded a tip and stood at our table and kept saying TIP OVER AND OVER AGAIN! The food was cold and the service was spotty
author: Lindsay ..

description: Horrible service! They took forever to take our order. We arrived before their normal customers but  were served last. The owner did not speak a word of English. Terrible experience!!!
author: Marj J.

description: We had a great experience the chinese food is the bomb.We got Snow peas with beef and the sparerib is to died for it had a crisp and sweet and sour flavor. Everyone should try it
author: June D.

description: Excellent Chinese Food for dinner!! Good o' home cooked Toi San Style food!!  Has my favorite dish - "Hom Dan Jin Gee Yuek Beng". They do not disappoint... still the best Chinese comfort food in town!
author: Patricia M.

description:
The food isn't amazing. And I grew up on Chinese food. There are a few pictures in the menu, but it's not going to get you very far. --bring someone who speaks Chinese. 

We ordered 3 dishes. Seafood wonton soup, watercress vegetables and fish filet. I wasn't impressed by any of the dishes. 
Seafood wonton soup - base of the soup tasted like chicken msg (the kind my mother made when I was a child)
The vegetables - was oddly $9 for no protein. I think the dish was alright, because all you do is sauteed it in a wok 

Fish filet --- it must have been bland, because I don't remember.

I did like that the New Woey Loy Goey opened late. My opening statement is 'the food isn't amazing,' but I rather eat than sleep hungry. Lol. My friend and I went at 9:30, and they served us. The place was roaring with Chinese families and really made the atmosphere feel authentic. I guess it's a family favorite for some in SF. 

Overall, I still stand that the food is 2 stars. The place isn't clean, but it's certainly Chinese (which reminds me of my childhood) which I award it 3 stars. Making my true vote 2.5

Side note: I'm offended they didn't offer me chopsticks. They gave me a fork. And the tea sucks.
author: Thomas K.

description: Bizarre... We walk in after a recommendation from a bartender across the street...the woman pointed to a table and we sat, she handed us menus and even gave us hot tea a few moments later.. there we are chatting away (our backs to the whole restaurant) and then we realize that the lady never came back to take our order....................we turn around and THEY ARE ALL SITTING CHOWING DOWN ON NOODLES AND RICE...all of them.... and they just stared at us.. we were upset and super hungry at that point that we said screw it and walked off. such a bizarre experience. we looked forward to eating something in china town.. oh well... skip the duck tongue...
author: Christina G.

description:
Love the fresh veggies and food! Feels very authentic.. may miss as u walk down the street because u need to go down some stairs. 
Again, the food is so fresh and good.. the man is making/rolling fresh won tons right as I write this review. Try it!
author: Patricia G.

description:
Chinatown, San Francisco, CA:  What a funny looking name for a restaurant.
"New And Peaceful Cafe" is a loose translation.

After reading through a number of posted menus in Chinatown at near 9 pm, and consulting with yelp, we decided we would try our luck here for late takeout dinners. The lunch specials seem to be available all day.

FOOD
Chicken Chow Fun: generous, enough for 2
Bittermelen with Blackbeans and Beef--all so tender, over white rice
Lotus Root with sliced Pork and wood fungus, over white rice (lotus root still too firm, but was seasoned decently)

Staff provided friendly service,  answered my questions, gave prompt service. Good comfort Cantonese food! Went back the next day for Filet Rock Cod with Bean Cake Rice.

$18.25 for the three dishes!

Original restaurant opened in 1934.

NOTE: We've had the Beef with Bittermelon rice ($4.95) again and it is consistently great!! Beef Chow Fun with Chinese Broccoli was fresh, tender,  and they made it less salty as requested. Free soup was included with dining in.
author: Shal W.

description:
9/17/17

Omg this place automatically took 15% for gratuity from us.  We paid in cash & there were 3 of us!  Is that even legal?   When has tipping been made mandatory?  What country do these people think they're in that they can just TAKE tip?  

I'm going to call someone about this & make sure they don't do this to other people.
author: Marie E.

description:
My parents brought my family to this basement restaurant and it was quite an experience. Felt like it could be a dive in Hong Kong in the 1970s.  Most of the patrons were Chinese speaking, which is a good  sign at a Chinese restaurant.  Some of the wait staff did not speak English.

The menu included a special with five dishes plus "house soup" for under $40 plus a charge for rice.  The dishes were salt and pepper shrimp with heads, garlic sautéed mustard greens, deep fried pork chops, cold chicken with a ginger and salt dipping sauce and steamed pork hash.  A red bean dessert soup was also included. 

We thought the food was really flavorful and a great deal, but about two hours after dinner, my son and I both had headaches.  Not sure if it was from MSG or maybe we were dehydrated from too much salt

We will try another time and see if we get the headaches again
author: Joanna S.

description: This place is hard to find .my friend said it was really good food..ee ordered a 9 course meal . Food came quickly.  Soup was marginal.  Lobster was great . Sweet pork chops were tender and flavorful.  We really enjoyed  the meal it came with a whole fish.rice was an extra charge.this was the best meal we had on this trip. It is a joke in the wall and their English is not very good.  Prices were reasonable.  Definitely  would go back
author: Anthony K.

description: Plenty to choose from on the menu. Prices are extremely reasonable. We had the Beef Chow Fun w/Bean Sprouts and a shrimp/chicken w/greens dish (forgot the name). Both were very good and filling & we had leftovers. There are many many restaurants to choose in the area but I will be back to this one to try more dishes.
author: David G.

description: A hidden gem in Chinatown, very fast and cheap. Almost $6.50 per dish including a soup!
author: Nicholas H.

description: We had the chicken fried rice, sweet and sour chicken, and chow mein. Over all pretty good and quite inexpensive considering the area. Quick service and friendly staff an clean would give 4.5 but that's not an option. Good experience would go again.
author: Katya W.

description: Exactly what we expected to find in China Town. Loved the experience and the loud hustling bustling ambience. Open until 9:30pm  very helpful considering most other places are closed.
author: vanessa v.

description:
I wanted to eat at an authentic Frisco Chinese restaurant where the food had not been Westernized for timid palates, and a local friend suggested this establishment.

We had to walk down a flight of stairs to get to this modest looking restaurant. I was glad that the place was packed with Chinese customers (always a good sign) and we grabbed the only table that was still free.

Our meal started with a free soup which was a very good bitter melon & pork soup -- I had experienced this ritual (the offering of a free soup to start the meal) in Chinese restaurants in Toronto's Chinatown. Glad to have another opportunity to enjoy it.

We ordered:
   Roast duck -- very good
   Braised filet of rock cod -- very good
   Mustard green -- very good
   Lamb stew in pot -- very good
   And one Tsing Tao beer.

The portions were very generous, and the four of us could not finish the food. The total bill came to $59 (tip included) -- a modest charge for a very good and satisfying dinner for four. But I give the restaurant 4* instead of 5 because the service was very marginal -- the wait staff did not speak much English (it was impossible to ask them to describe a dish, "Everything GOOD" one of them kept on repeating as answer to my many questions) and it took three exhortations before my wife could get her beer late into the meal despite having ordered it with the food early on.
author: Trong D.

description: Their food here is AMAZING! Priced very reasonably and service is not bad either considering your in chinatown. It's a little hidden because you have to walk down the stairs to get inside. I ordered for a tomato beef over rice and egg prawns over rice. Asked for no salt and they made it completely the way I asked for! Which a lot of times restaurants forget and do add some salt. Their prices can be as cheap as $7 for a plate of food and rice, which is kind of impossible for a dinner meal. I love this place! One thing is that I hope they can extend longer hours, this way I'll come 3x a week!
author: Stella L.

description:
My Girlfriend and I were in San Francisco this past weekend, for a short personal get-away!  One of our points of interest was to visit China Town.  As we were walking down the street, we decided to have a early dinner right there in China Town.  This place was a definite hidden gem for both locals and tourists!

We, at some point and can't remember why, decided to turn down a street.  Once we crossed, we saw two young ladies looking at a menu posted on a wall.  We looked it over, the prices seemed very reasonable.  The variety was awesome.

The fun and interesting part was their entrance.  You had to walk down a staircase to get to the restaurant's front door.

It's a very casual atmosphere, authentic, and maybe a family run business.  They have some family and combination meals available.  You can also order everything a la carte.  Everything we ordered was awesome!

By the end of our dinner, we were enjoying our dinner and engrossed in the Chinese fight movie the very friendly employees were watching.

This is a must visit!
author: Manny S.

description:
Had another fantastic dinner at this restaurant. We had steamed fresh fish and garlic stir fried pea shoots. Delish!!!!!
The decor is not great but food is delicious and very reasonably priced. 
If you want good 'wok hay' this is the restaurant you want to go to.
author: Linda C.

description:
Whenever my sisters and I stop here for lunch, we always go for the snails (escargots, anyone?).  The French aren't the only ones eating this delicacy; the Chinese do, too.

This was a family outing for lunch, but we decided to forego the snails and order plenty of rice plates - chicken & Chinese mushroom, steak cube & Chinese broccoli, curry beef tongue, filet flounder & bok choy, beef tendon & turnip; a platter of beef chow fun and a claypot of spicy eggplants.

Included with our lunch was the house soup, which was flavorful (could have had a slight amount of MSG, but not noticeable to give me a headache thereafter).  

I ordered the chicken & Chinese mushroom rice plate (my favorite).  It was a generous portion of chicken, Chinese mushroom, green beans and carrots.  Since it was family style dining, we all shared what each of us ordered.

Everything was delicious.  The eggplants had quite a kick to it...spicy (slices of fresh jalapeno peppers and red pepper flakes).  I only ate one eggplant and washed it down with a lot of tea.  I am somewhat allergic to very spicy food, so I have to be extremely careful on how much I consume.  My sisters raved about this dish and would order it again.  

The price for our meal was reasonable...about $8.00 per person.  Not bad having lunch there and leaving with a full stomach.

The hostess and the waitresses were also attentive and made sure we were content with the food we ordered, and our teapot was filled with hot tea.

Finally, a funny thing happened on my way to the restroom.  I did not know the light switch was outside of the ladies' restroom.  Thank goodness I had my cellphone in my pocket and I kept pressing the middle button, playing my ringtone (Purple Rain by Prince) just so I would have some light in there.  At least I wasn't singing that gospel song, "This little light of mine, I'm gonna let it shine".  Another female customer turned the light on after I washed my hand and opened the door.  I thanked her for being helpful (yeah, kind of embarrassing - mho yee see).  I have to laugh at my own foible.
author: Carol C.

description:
While roaming the streets of chinatown for the first time, I came across this restaurant. I have to say I was very impressed by how authentic their Chinese food was. 

They start you off with a hot bone soup with daikons (white radish) and carrots which was veryyyy good. 

Refer to my photos to see what we ordered but compared to other Chinese restaurants I tried in San Francisco, this one was the best!
author: Sarah C.

description: First time in San Francisco and we decided to eat our first meal in Chinatown. We were just at the curb when we smell the aroma of their dishes. So we gave it a shot. We ordered Chinese style fried chicken, roast duck wonton soup, sweet and sour pork and shrimp fried rice. I'm giving 5 stars for all the dishes because my whole family loved it. We even ordered some for take out. The staff are very courteous and friendly. They make sure everything is being taken care of. They'd even refill our soup! Will definitely visit this restaurant again.
author: Rei H.

description:
Retro.  
Made me think of the good old days when we ate like there was no tomorrow.  Three, four bowls of rice was no big deal and what is trans fat again?!  We'd eat like there was no tomorrow because we'd burn it off playing sports and keeping active.
As responsibilities like paying bills and saving for our future became priorities, we were no longer the playahz we thought we were.
That's why when you find restaurants that offer lunch or rice plates under $8.00, you take notice.  With my lunch rotation place on vacation, this place came to mind.  My order?  Minced beef and egg over rice (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=kmYCtvpKT-Fsiw8nBKA8Cg),  Cantonese staple... think scaled down loco moco.  Flavors were solid but I like a little "kick" to my food, so added some Yank Sing chili sauce and it was complete.  Sweetness from the peas, salty richness from the oyster sauce, offset by the runny yolk.  Top it with the spiciness and my $7.00 meal brought a Cheshire grin to my face.  Calling it my flavorfied loco moco!
The soup was flavorful though one note as there were no other ingredients in my container (suspect it was lotus roots boiled with pork pieces, lean given the broth color.  
Those growing up in Chinatown will remember this as the third choice for casual American comfort food (Sun Wah Kue and Jackson Cafe being the more popular choices).  They made a KILLER roast pork with gravy and cabbage back in the day.  The crispness of the pork skin and the melt in your mouth tenderness of the pork and fatty trimmings were unbeatable; similar to the now closed Mariposa Cafeteria.  After closing, the chef owner/partner of the unparalleled 1980's Kam Lok (another basement restaurant) broke off and took over this space.  The cuisine stayed the same though the kitchen's skill level slipped a bit.
Solid budget eat spot with old time cuisine, but might not be a good idea to bring a date here...  unless you are really hurting in the pocketbook.
author: Mike C.

description:
Walked in from the street. The place looked promising; maybe it'd be a place with amazing food but with a weird setting. If you're bit accustomed to the Chinese culture (ex. Eating with strangers if they don't have enough tables), then don't come here. 
Food: 4/5 
Environment: 2/5
Service: 2/5
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Great black bean sauce snails.

The entrance is not very inviting and the air in dining room is heavy with cooking smells. But don't let his deter you, some of their dishes are really good.

Here are some of the things I have tried:

Salt and Pepper Fried Chicken Wings - Very Good

Hot and Sour Soup -  I love a good Hot and Sour Soup but I am not wild about theirs. The fermented flavor is stronger than I like for this dish.

Black Bean Sauce Snails 
This was the  main reason to be here. This place is known for its snails in black bean sauce. Warning: If you are new to snails they are a little scary looking when you are presented with a huge bowl of them. 

Being an asian snail first timer, I made a few embarrassing mistakes. Hopefully you can do better.

Mistake #1.
First make sure you order your snails spicy. I did not get it spicy the first time. Snails are all about texture. The taste is not that remarkable, so you need a bold sauce for it all to work well.

Mistake #2
The next thing to know is you should not chow into these like you might a french escargot appetizer. French escargots have been cleaned and had the nasty bits removed for you. They don't do that for you in authentic Chinese restaurants. The snails digestive tracts are still attached and taste totally awful. They need to be removed. You only eat the meaty foot bit and not the strange looking sacks that are full of sand and snail poo.
 
Mistake #3
This restaurant is generous with their snails. You get a lot of snails. So mistake #3 is If you get #1 and #2 wrong, don't eat all the snails by yourself. You will not feel so good if you eat a big bowl of snail poo.

After figuring this all out, the snails here are pretty darned good.

Bon Appetit
author: David T.

description:
This place is becoming one of my family's to-go place for dinner. This place is one of the most authentic restaurant you can get. You can tell just by coming here because they been in business for decades and a lot of the customers are actually locals. Plus... if a Chinese person says that the food that they're paying for is actually better than home-cooked meal, that is saying something. Which happened to my family at this restaurant, and trust me, my mom never says that about any restaurant...even if they're a michelin-starred restaurant. What's even better is that this place is affordable! They have single individual noodle/rice plates that range around $5-8 and family style plates that ranges around $8-12 each (excluding higher range dishes like lobster). The service is great- always attentive and nice. Unlike most restaurants in CT, they do not treat tourists any "higher" than a local. 

Anyways to food...generally me and my parents order the same dishes so here is a breakdown

Recommended: 
-Seafood + Tofu in a clay pot: my personal favorite. there is a variety of seafood (squid, shrimp, scallops) cooked with fried tofu, mushrooms and lettuce. Love this! Comes hot and stays hot.

-Salt and pepper fried pork chop: would also recommend. Pork chops are fried and tossed with jalapeno peppers and salt. the pork chops are tender and seasoned perfectly.

-minced pork + garlic sauce eggplant in clay pot: my boyfriend's personal favorite. the eggplants are sliced thinly and not even overcooked.

-steamed oysters with black bean: the oysters are fat! they give you about seven and they don't even skimp and give you dead cheap oysters. 


"Meh" dishes:
-fried flatfish (flounder) : sorry, I don't know what's the fish is called in English but it is deep fried flatfish served over a sugar soy sauce. This is probably the only dish my parents did not like. Major complain is that the fish was not crispy enough.

-shrimp with cashew: we ordered this thinking it was fried shrimp w/ walnuts in that white mayo sauce but some miscommunication and we ended up with this. The cashews were soggy, and overall there wasn't anything special about this dish.

-chinese style snails: my mom's complaint was that it was too salty, my dad's was that there wasn't enough taste. I thought overall it was okay.. but personally this dish wasn't anything special. it simply tastes like snail stir fried with soy sauce.
author: Jenny N.

description:
Basement Chinese restaurant in SF Chinatown!  One of the best dining restaurants in Chinatown whenever you and your crew want to dine in Chinatown!  This place conveniently holds large, dine-in gatherings!

D o  O r d e r - 

Stir-fried Black Bean Snails (Tian Luo) - Don't be alarmed by the name!  It's like Escargot, but in black bean sauce!  It's so good here!  The flavor of the chopped up garlic and black bean sauce compliments extremely well with the snails!  

Stir Fried Pea Sprouts - You need some kind of veggies to go with the meal and this is the best veggie dish!

Steamed Oysters - Topped with black bean and soy sauce, this platter is great for an opening appetizer!

Fried Fish - Battered up and surrounded by soy sauce, this is a must get entree!  Trust me!  The thin bones of the fish is fried up as well - so you can eat that too, at your discretion!

Sweet and Sour Pork Chops - I like how they deep fry it to a point that it is still crisp and the taste of the  sweet and sour sauce is well made!

All in all, most of their dishes ordered up here, is generally guaranteed delicious!  It just depends on whether you feel like having something salty, sweet or sour.  Do get all those kinds of flavors to fulfill your taste buds' needs!

I like how it is underground and it's easily overlooked.  That gives this place a bit of a seclusion and a hideout from the normal dining crowd.  This spot is definitely low key - as if it has no one to impress.  Food is great and affordable, you get the attention from the servers because this place is small too and the place offers a quaint ambiance.  Impressive.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
this place was so legit! my friends and i came AFTER lunch #1 at hang ah tea house because we werent satisfied at all! so someone suggested this spot and we got - ginger crab, the meat patty specialty dish, and egg white scallop fried rice. 

everything was sooo tasty and flavorful.  seriously so impressed. haha. prices are beyond reasonable, so that was definitely an added bonus! :) WILL BE BACK FOR MORE.
author: Christina L.

description: Food was good and inexpensive, but the service was awful! We waited an hour just to get menus.
author: Noeli T.

description: Unfortunately, though this restaurant is usually consistent in food quality, service is getting poorer and sketchier. Check your bill--they have twice charged a 15% service charge/automatic gratuity without stating or notifying our party. The most recent time, we noticed the additional amount after they ran the credit card. They said "because it's Chinese New Year." ...
author: Emily L.

description: Great food, always on point. We bring our tourist Family' s here to eat and there has not been any disappointments.
author: Kathy A.

description: Cheap and tasty. We had their special stramed chicken, which was awesome. Their scallop kung pao was very good also. Kung pao was flavorful and scallop was soft. Their wonton soup and roast duck was ok but good for being cheap. Our waitress was also friendly.
author: Jess S.

description:
Tried it out after months of walking by and saying we should try it.  Ordered pork spareribs in black bean sauce rice plate.  It was a delicious lunch plate.  Lots of Asian patrons, the resto itself is spotless.  So many options, must go back.  

Also very reasonable prices.
author: Donna H.

description:
New Woey Loy Goey has been a long time fav. haven't been back mush lately. 

yep. i've been seeing other eats. New Woey is now just an eat in the past. either their food has changed or my taste buds have.

oxtail stew over rice (5.95)
-sauce a little lacking
-oxtail just ok, not meaty, not so tasty
-carrots, potato tastier than the oxtails.
steamed oysters in half shell w/black bean(9.95)
-oysters scrawny, not big and plumb.
-ok taste.
comped house soup
-tasty, with a tad of msg.

leftovers:
-food good value, 4 star
-sad to say i won't be back, food isn't exciting anymore.
bland and filling, yes.
-old style home cooking that's changed or is it me?
author: Victor G.

description:
Food was five stars, but slow service took one star away. 

Food:
Salt and pepper pork chop
Meat pie, it was crispy and salty but awesome with rice.
Fried little fish (dou chun yuir), awesome sweet crispy
Walnut prawns 

Everything was as expected or better. Prices really affordable. 

Service was decent and friendly but as a lunch spot for work they have slow service. I want to come back often but can't take two hour lunches for the one by one dishes to slowly come out.
author: Lily V.

description:
This review is not about the food, which was perfectly decent in a neighborhood full of decent Chinese food. It's about the absurdly slow service and being ignored by the staff. I chose this restaurant because it's across the street from a theatre where we had tickets to a show at 8pm. When we arrived at the restaurant at 7pm the dining room was about half full. We took our seats at an otherwise empty counter. 

After placing our order, three other gentlemen, each alone, sat down at the counter and eventually placed their orders. While we waited and waited, all three gentlemen received their appetizers, their main dishes and they finished eating, all before we even received our appetizer. I asked the waitress several times about our order, and she just pointed to the kitchen and said it was coming. Again and again. 

By the time our food finally arrived at 7:45, we had about 10 minutes to wolf the food down and pay our bill. The food tasted fine, but it's hard to enjoy when you're both rushing to eat and angry about feeling ignored.

I'm compelled to point out that those who were served faster were all Chinese and we are not. Possibly a coincidence, and maybe not.
author: Tosco R.

description:
From the outside this restaurant does not look very special. We were looking for a place that served traditional Peking Duck. My guests were a little skeptical about the food, and ordered lamb as an alternative.. However once the Peking Duck arrived it was devoured by everyone at the table. All in all a wonderful safe, clean, and very enjoyable meal.

One small downside to ordering here -they don't take AMEX. Otherwise, I might give them another star.

All in all a safe bet if you plan to visit Chinatown, SF. And worth a repeat visit.
author: Neil H.

description:
Pros

Inexpensive
Tomato beef chow crispy mein
Peking spareribs
House chow fun
Oxtail stew
Beef stew
Free house soup
Locals eat here
Cool basement eatery
Counter seating if you're alone
Clean
Cultural experience

Cons

Tight seating 
Funky ass bathroom
Cultural experience 

Will repeat.  Especially when funds are low
author: John L.

description:
hey for the prices here the food is excellent, it's no R&G Lounge or Hakkasan, but a truly great "hole in wall."

I suggest this place for tourists - it's authentic cheap and has a huge menu. Most all your standard cantonese dishes.
author: Phantom Of Yel P.

description: This is old fashion Chinese food! It's really busy and kinda outdated, but really good mom and pops style Chinese food. You have to try it. Their chicken wings, chow mein, chow fun and fried wonton soup is my usual!
author: Adam L.

description:
Amazing and utterly authentic Chinese place in Chinatown (duh, but still, many are much more touristy). And there's that perfect name! You have to go down stairs seemingly into a basement to get there.

Seriously, I think there was one other non-Chinese person there, and it was packed. The waiter interrogated my wife to make sure she really wanted salted fish (she did) because apparently most tourists don't know what that means, or like it when they get it. 

Anyway, it's the best duck plate you will ever get for $4.50. How do they even do that? The fried oysters were large (good but not great) and the salted fish was also good. You get a hot tea (like, super hot) the second you sit down.

Can't recommend this enough! New Woey Loy Goey!

Also worth noting the single TV had a Serie A Italian soccer game on (in Chinese).
author: Greg M.

description:
Solid place for real Chinese food. Good and efficient service. There's always more than one waiter. 

Food comes out quickly. Free house soup. Great lunch special deals. 

My family and I have been coming here for years. We're Chinese, so my parents can be quite particular. Heck if I'm eating out with them, 100% of the time it's Chinese food. Ok maybe like 98%. :P The food is almost always consistently good and has good "wok air." Food isn't drenched in oil and salt like some places. Occasionally a dish will be a bit too salty or something. No big deal, it happens. We're a fan of the salted fish fried rice. They make good chow mein too. I like their pan fried noodles. Salted fish egg plant clay pot, yum! Good steamed catfish. Veggies dishes are always fresh. Water spinach (tung choy) with fermented bean curd! My brother always gets the salt and pepper squid/calamari. Pork blood done right with good amount of chives. 

Looking for a good Chinese restaurant in Chinatown? Go here!
author: Anna L.

description: We come here every year.  Real good food. Always say we're going to try a new spot but just doesn't seem right. Be back next year love the green beans & garlic.
author: Monica V.

description:
Customer service was great and the staff was attentive and friendly.
I tried the hot and sour soup which was super yummy!
I had the Chinese Broccoli and Beef Chow Mein lunch special which was really good and I would definitely order it again. It sure hit the spot on a rainy day in SF.
The prices are very reasonable and you get a lot of food for the price.
author: Kelly B.

description:
Wo Hop, my favorite restaurant in NY's Chinatown is located in the basement, as is Woey Loy Goey.  Wo Hop has been open for as long as I can remember, perhaps beat by Woey Loy, which opened in 1934!

Based on Yelp reviews, I expected a fabulous meal -- but truth be told, while good, it wasn't great.  The chow fun, which others raved about, was typical.  We perked it up with soy sauce.  I liked that the braised tofu came with bok choy and straw mushrooms, but the tofu itself was bland.  Perhaps our favorite dish was orange chicken. 

The menu has a lot on it, plenty geared to the Asian palate.  Prices are very affordable, and portions are big.  If you don't order touristy things, I suspect you'll have a more authentic and tastier meal than we did.  I also think that people without a particular affinity for Chinese food, would find New Woey Loy Goey to be pretty good.
author: Meredith R.

description: Great place to go if you're in Chinatown.  Place is very affordable.  Some dishes were outright amazing but some were a little bland. The salt and pepper ribs are just ok but the lo mein is very good. I hit this place up whenever I got to SF
author: Syd B.

description: Pretty good. Other lines were so long and this seemed like a safe bet since there were several people inside. It quickly filled up. My kids at the Peking duck and loved it. Sweet service, good price and underrated for sure.
author: Sara J.

description:
We have become regulars here.  Free wifi is awesome but of course not the main reason but doesn't hurt!

What we really love about this place is all the 'soul food' items they offer, generous portion and the great price.  

Free house soup is always a plus.  

More on actual dishes later!
author: Gloria H.

description: DELICIOUS AND CHEAP. That is what I have to say. The dinners were a good size of meat and either chow mein or rice and they were FIVE DOLLARS. So delicious. It is totally authentic too, right in the middle of Chinatown and you have to go downstairs to get to it. Our waiter was really nice, even though he was confused by my English and thought i ordered two plates instead of one. Totally my fault and not his. He got a good tip;)
author: Julia D.

description:
1st time trying this place after living close to Chinatown for nearly 40 years.

Pros: Fairly clean, good food, free wifi, nice staff...all great positives to have.

Nuetral: Tall people - WATCH you head going down those stairs!

Cons: Waiter did Chinese math on us....On a bill that should have been $18, we were charged $19...maybe it was by mistake, maybe it wasn't...I'm Chinese and I know math like Bo knows sports. It's only a friggin dollar, but it's the principle that matters.

It will probably be another 40 years before I return.
author: Peter L.

description:
An underground hole-in-the-wall restaurant that serves authentic, first-rate Chinese food with reasonable prices and quick service. 

Make sure to try their beef chow fun. It is the best! 

I will definitely eat here again the next time I visit San Francisco.
author: Anna B.

description: Was looking for good beef chow fun with that wok flavor that asians like. Did not find it here. Noodles were very oily and beef was chewy, not tender. And NO wok flavor. Place is pretty big for Chinatown, with a few round tables for 6+ people. Tons of Chinese local and a few Americans. Ok ambience and bad service like at most asian places.
author: Yenn T.

description: Total hole in the wall but so good. Try the lamb stew   I don't like lamb but thought it was delicious. Will be back
author: Sandra R.

description: So after a few years I came back to San Fran and wanted to eat here because I remembered it being so good.  I would no longer give it 5 stars, down to 4, still really good. The Mongolian beef wasn't as good as I remembered it to be.  Over all I was pretty satisfied, service was good just nothing really stood out as being amazing but could have been we just didn't order the right dishes. The prices are still amazing though.
author: Ben C.

description:
Wow what a find ! so if you want the real deal and great prices check this place out.
Staff on top of it food piping hot and delicious.
author: Kent S.

description:
I really loved the atmosphere of this place, a little divey and a little homey all at the same time. It's located in the basement of an old building in Chinatown and you have to take the stairs down into this quaint little restaurant. 

Some of the staff did not speak English but they were still helpful and tried their best to communicate with us. I felt kind of bad because I wish I could've communicated with them. Mr. Lee, the manager of the place who does speak English, was very hospitable and attentive to our party of 7. We came in around 9:00 pm. Service was quick as well.

We ordered Scalloped Fried Rice with egg whites, Snow Pea Shoots with garlic, Deep Fried Flounder, some sort of steamed chicken dish, Hot & Sour soup, Beef Chow Mein with tender greens, and some sort of egg omelette dish, I forgot the name of it. 

The Scalloped fried rice was delicious, a bit too salty for my taste but I liked the flavor on the scallops. The Snow Pea Shoots with garlic was tasty and probably one of my favorite dishes of the night. I just like the combination of garlic and a little bit of soy sauce with vegetables, it's so simple but delicious. The Hot & Sour soup wasn't my favorite. There was something off putting about the taste, I couldn't quite put my finger on it. It just tasted bland and had a weird texture to it. The Beef Chow Mein with greens was delicious as well, I thought the beef was cooked perfectly. My family and I really enjoyed the Deep Fried Flounder that we ordered another dish. The fish was tender and slid right off the bone. We also ordered a steamed chicken dish, it reminded me of Hainanese Chicken (though I'm not too sure if that was the name at this restaurant. I completely forgot what this dish was called). Nevertheless, it was nice and tender and the red sauce that came with it wasn't too spicy. The last dish was some sort of egg omelette with vegetables inside. It was just okay. The omelette itself was a little soggy.

Overall, I had a good experience. My family enjoyed the food as well. I will definitely come back to try some other dishes on the menu. The service was great and one of the reasons why I would come back to this restaurant. It's always nice to have friendly people helping us.
author: Andrea S.

description:
Was seeking a local Dive Dining experience to share with friends pre Chinatown New Years parade. OMG! this place rocks with quality, portions and fun dive-styled ambience down the stairs with the dining counter.  

3 of us left with sides bursting:
Orange Chicken - could be 1 of the best I've ever had in my City by the Bay
Beef with Bok Choy  - greens cooked perfectly whole & beef melted in our mouths
Chow Fun Red Spicy Beef - WOW Fun to have this Chow Fun - noodles are perfect
Mu Shu Pork - Great filling, and pancakes were good & many
Tsing Tao Beers - can't go wrong
BILL :  $50  

My native SF self  has now found my gotta-go-to spot cuz it's spot on with authentic Chinese food.
author: Judi B.

description: I came for a visit in San Francisco and I had to have my Chinese food fix. At first, this cute restaurant was a bit sketchy but their tasty menu drew me in. I came around 12 pm and it was slightly crowded. I saw on Yelp reviews that they give each table a bowl of their soup of the day but I didn't receive it. The service was fast and quick. The food was on point. Everything was so tasty! I ordered 8 dishes and the bill came out to be $60. Great food, low prices. This hole in the wall restaurant was a score.
author: Rose S.

description: This place has very good, inexpensive food. When ever I find my self in down town SF and craving some Chinese I hit this place up. It's kind of hidden so you have to keep your eye for the stairs that take you underground.
author: Elliott D.

description:
Common prices for a decent cheap meal these days in Chinatown will start at at least $6. Come to New Woey Loy Goey and they start at $3.95! It's old school and straight up locals in here, many sitting at the counter and dining alone. (That would include me.)

I love their mapo tofu. They load it with tons of tofu and ground pork and it has a nice, spicy kick to it.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
Delicious chinese food. Pricing was very cheap and the portions were great. Dishes were seasoned well, and I had absolutely no complaint about individual dishes. 

Would definitely return!
author: Sung K.

description: Restaurant closes at 10pm we arrived at 9:25pm sat down and was told "You Order NOW" huh, no thank you for coming can I get you a drink. Then at least two people sat and stared at us while we looked at the menu not even 1 minute later was asked what we wanted. End of story we got up and left. Chinese food doesn't take 30 minutes to make, and I get you close in 30 minutes but you are open right now and there is no need to be rude to people coming into your establishment.
author: JD T.

description:
Very impressed! Wow. Woey Loy Goey restaurant is truly a hidden gem. Me and my friend were wondering around the streets of Chinatown, searching for a place that had good noddles for a VERY cheap price. My wallet had only $10 and my friends wallet only held around $5. Thanks to one of those ladies who pass out pamphlets advertising their restaurants, we would of never stumbled across this place. The lady handed us a pamphlet to a different restaurant, but we told her the prices were too much for us. We told her we were looking for a place with amazing noodles and rice dishes for a cheap price. She told us about Woey Loy Goey and that we would like their menu. She proceeded to give us directions and we listened carefully. 

We walked toward Woey Loy Goey and couldn't see the restaurant anywhere. We finally noticed the bright pink menus posted outside, pointing towards a staircase going underground. We looked at each other with a curious smirk and made our way down the stairs.

Inside, the restaurant looked like an authentic Chinese Restaurant. The fish tanks and large, circular tables with fresh smelling table clothes was a good sign for me. The waiter handed us our menus, and we were excited to order. I ordered the Cashew Chicken, and my friend ordered the Chow Mein (I think).  

When we received our food, I was very pleased with the size. For very little money, I got nice, large, fresh pieces of chicken simmered in an amazing sauce with fresh cashews, vegetables, and white steamed rice. My friends Chow Mein looked just as good. As I finally dug Into my meal, I was even more pleased. I am very picky when it comes to Chinese food, and love the cuisine greatly. Woey Loy Goey lives up to my expectation. 

I definitely recommend Woey Loy Goey. The service was fast, food was fresh, and it's cheap, overall great Chinese food.
author: Emmanuella Z.

description:
We wandered around Chinatown looking for something to eat. We had our trusty Yelp App out as we passed restaurant after restaurant. Finally, it came to a boiling point. We were hungry and getting anxious to find a place to sit down and put something into our stomachs. Most places seemed to have either poor or varying reviews. We then came across New Woey Loy Goey and a restaurant a few doors down. New Woey looked a little sketchy, as we'd have to walk down the stairs to a below street level area. The place down a few doors had images of Obama eating there on the outside widow and a long wait. Nope. Back to New Woey. What a surprise! When we entered, we there are only a couple people inside. We were greeted graciously. By the end of our meal, the place was packed with locals. You gotta figure, if the locals are eating there in droves, they know where the good food is. 

We got a couple orders of potstickers, an order of bbq pork fried rice, wonton soup, and a couple orders of chicken chow mein. Everything was real cheaply priced, but we got a mountain of food on our plate. Everything was so freakin' good. I devoured my fried rice and even though bordering on completely full...decided to taste the other plates as my family and friends were full and just about done. Won Ton soup was beyond superb, but the chow mein was out of this world good. 

Living up in Santa Rosa, you think you have good Chinese food in your area until you go somewhere like New Woey Loy Goey. Staff was great and attentive. Just look past the exterior and fact you have to walk down a flight of stairs to an underground area to get through the doors. Inside is a hidden gem of a place where you won't be disappointed. I'm already thinking of a when I can go back.
author: Eric M.

description: Definitely sketch from the outside but shocking delicious! After a looong day in the city my dad decided he wanted to have dinner in Chinatown. I was very nervous as I'm a very picky eater and don't really like trying new things, however, my family & the boy convinced me to give it a shot and wow was I impressed. I'm knocking them 1 star because their service could of been better! Took about 15 minutes after our party sat for anyone to get our drink order, we then ordered family style and some items were forgotten but aside from those little hiccups everything else was great!
author: Monique F.

description:
I haven't been there since 1963 - 64 during the early hippie days. Woey Loy Goey was on street level at that time. I still remember one of the dishes served then was a generous pile of steamed white rice, 1/6th steamed cabbage wedge, 3 good pork chops with some gravy. They called that "the worker's lunch special". All that for 
$ 3.50. I kid you not. I gave it 5 stars from the memories. Glad to see Woey Loy Goey  still serves food, even under new ownership. The client good will must be numerically tremendous due to the fact that it has existed for over 50 years. Glad to have discovered it still exists on Yelp. I'll give it a try with family in tow not too long from now.
Also, thanks for the post done by the Vietnam vet who has Taiwan friends and such. It was a real kick to read that review as well.
author: Saiful R.

description:
Sitting at the counter writing this review. Had to wait and wait for someone to take my order while sitting with a water glass  of tea. Finally asked the women next to me what the secret  was to getting an order taken, and she got one of the staff's attention and that worked. She also told me they have dishes that are not on the menu,  but someone else will have to cofirm that. 
My food appeared very shortly after that. It was okay. I hit a little ginger and a little star anise in individual bites, but those seemed to be the only two traces of seasoning in my seafood combo rice plate. 
My helpful counter mate told me I would probably get a bowl of soup too. I did not though others waited on after me did. I never got more tea, or even saw the server again. No tip was left, and I left disappointed that the idea of having a good meal in Chinatown did moy work out.
author: margaret w.

description: Awesome Chinese food place, serving South Cantonese style cooking (according to a tour guide). If you're on a limited budget, but still want authentic Chinese food for a meal, this is your place. For $11, I had 6 wonderfully cooked potstickers and a huge plate of beef chow fun that certainly left me feeling satisfied. And the price was great as well, especially for San Francisco
author: Ben S.

description:
Dishonest restaurant!
I had to use my credit card so I asked waiter about the total of my order, if it's over the $20 minimum. Actually, I knew for sure it's over $20, but I asked anyway to make sure. The waiter told me, almost, but you need to order one more dish. WTH!!I said it's fine, and, guess what, the waiting is like forever!!
Finally we got all our dishes but the quality is below average. 
I asked for check, and the bill only showed the dish names and the total charge, and the amount is way higher than my estimate. Turned out they include the tax and 15% TIPS!!!WTH!!!
Very disappointed with the dishes but more disappointed with the restaurant itself. I will never go to this restaurant AGAIN!!
author: Kitty C.

description:
I knew this place was going to have good food when I watched the tables fill up after we arrived and we were still the only white people there.  We did one of the combos with hot and sour soup, wontons, potstickers, Mongolian beef, cashew chicken and subbed the fried rice with chow mein.

Hot and sour soup is one of my favorite soups of all time.  This place may have the best hot and sour soup I've ever had.  The noodles were really good and the Mongolian beef was spicy, like it's supposed to be.  Loved it all.
author: Shannon D.

description:
My friends and fellow Yelpers and I had dinner at this restaurant a few days ago.  After a horrible day of climbing hills [us Arizonians aren't use to the physical work-out, lol] and battling face-burning winds, we stumbled upon this eatery and boy are we glad we did!

We had ordered the Tung Lok fried rice, ginger and onion oysters, Szechuan tofu, mustard greens and crab [sauce], and Peking duck.  Now for the breakdown:

Tung Lok Friend Rice - This is basically a yung chow friend rice.  It has some peas, multiple meats, and stir-fried using white rice instead of soy sauce drenched fried rice.  It was pretty standard and not too bad!

Ginger & Onions Oysters - Delicious but I thought the oysters would be on the half-shell.

Szechuan Tofu - Also delicious!  It had some preserved veggies in it, peas, and some pork bits like an authentic Ma Po Tofu dish.

Mustard Greens & Crab - The dish name is kind of deceiving.  This dish DOES have some real crab bits but it's made into an eggy sauce [think of Shrimp & Lobster Sauce].  It's pretty delicious!

Peking Duck - Super delicious!  It's probably my favorite dish.

Overall, the food was excellent and so was the service.  The staff workers are incredibly friendly and strike up pleasant conversation about my last name.  XD  Although the restaurant entrance is pretty scary and the decor isn't as glamorous as some of the other Chinatown restaurants are, it's a pretty darn delicious place!
author: Joyce W.

description: Great find in Chinatown!  Pot stickers, chicken fried rice, and prawns in lobster sauce filled our tummies. Great flavors, attentive staff, and easy on the pocketbook!
author: Wendy K.

description:
Woey Loy Goey is American-style Chinese food, if that makes any sense. It's not Panda Express territory, but it's nothing truly exotic either.

Other than the prices (and the stairwell down), there's nothing that makes this place stand out from the hundreds of other restaurants in SF Chinatown. Well, there was the fact that they wouldn't let me leave because "I didn't tip enough." Apparently 15% is too low?
author: Casey S.

description:
The food does its job. Located underground. 

The service here is decent. They gave us another table's food but it was okay cause we gave it back right away. They did follow our request to have regular tofu instead of fried tofu in the seafood tofu sizzling pot. The food came out pretty fast except for the pig feet but I assume it takes a lot longer to cook. 

We requested less oil and no msg. I am pretty sure they didn't follow that request. The beef and choy dish was covered in oil. If you lift up a piece of choy it would be dripping in oil. 

Did come with complementary soup which tasted light and yummy. Overall it is a decent place so a solid 3 stars. I would come back.
author: Sarah C.

description:
beyond bad！！！I  will never go back.

Actually, I am not a new customer of this restaurant, the food was fine, but the service would make you crazy.
Today, I went to the restaurant with my boyfriend, and we only order a soup and a fish, because the price of the fish was so expensive, so my boyfriend asked how they calculate the price. the waiter said they  calculate by pound, do you believe it ?! god, 

then we said two dishes and some rice were enough for us, the waiter seemed not so happy when we said that, is that too less??, which made us so awkward.....

and, maybe they not happy, they gave us the rice 20 mins later after ordering for several times

after that, the worse situlation happened. when another group of people came in the the restaurant, they want the same fish dish like us, so the waiter pointes to our fish for more than five time, and asked them loudly like "IS this you want? you want this? is this? is this fish?...." oh god, so close, so loud, so dirty, so rude, didn't care about our feeling at all

last, when we pay the bill, the rude waiter demand 15% tip for her service, and I told her I was not satisfied with her service. what made shocked was that she did not say sorry, and even wanted to argue with us....and just at that time, another group of people came into the restaurant, she went directly to them with her fake smile and just ignored us

which made think they smile for money, if you have enough money to let them happy, going there maybe a good choice

this was my real experience today in this restaurant, make you choice, all in all, I will never go back again!
author: Weihui L.

description:
Ordered pork spareribs in black bean sauce rice plate. 
it was good
author: Alisher K.

description: Awesome restaurant like a little under ground hole in the wall. Really good food very affordable, and extremely delicious. I would recommend it to all my family and I have eaten there four times. We always order different things so 16 different meals and their all delicious. Their beef chow fun is delicious. I also would recommend the salted spare ribs are amazing far better than most other Chinese restaurants. Also if your feeling adventures they have delicious frog, I know many don't like the thought of frog, but hey it's amazing. It's a great little restaurant that I will most definitely be returning to and you should check it out as well.
author: Roman S.

description:
Very bad service, I want to take out a chow mein, but there were no forks or chopsticks.
Asking them to take, but the waiter attitude evil torture!
author: King L.

description:
Had some good old taishanese dishes that brought back memories of days past. Waitresses very friendly and food was good. That combined with the great value and low prices made for a memorable experience. If I find myself in San Francisco again I will go back for sure.

~ DaShawn
author: DaShawn H.

description: Happened upon this place on a Saturday afternoon. My husband needed a bathroom and we wanted a bite. Saw only Chinese (Asian) people coming out of this place so we walked down the steps and the place was 70% full (also a good sign) big menu. We ordered pot stickers and Beef Wonton  soup for hubby and War Wonton soup for me. Big bowls of soup with lots of goodies and lots of filled wontons. $19 and that included no charge hot tea. Wouldn't say it was better than any normal Chinese I have been to in my life but very good and a very low price. A locals place I would assume. Would go back again.
author: Lori S.

description:
Not a place for handicap persons to eat. It's got metal stairs that goes down below street level into the basement and the delivery guy drags his metal cart with boxes of food thump, thump, thump down the stairs into the back kitchen. 
The bathroom is weird. There are his and her stalls but you have to step up to a door which opens to a decent sized single stall bathroom with toilet, sink, electric blower that's worthless and paper towel holder.  
Hubby really wanted to come back here to re-live the good old days when they would come home from college across the Bay and go here to eat as it was one of the few places that would stay open until 2 AM.  

The portions are fairly generous if you like a lot of rice, it was practically 2 small bowls on your plate.  The entree portions are not that big. I tried the taro and pork over rice.  For under $6, the portion is generous. The taro was good with a brown gravy sauce.  The pork consisted of slices of dried, preserved thinly sliced pork. I didn't like it as I was expecting fresh pork belly. 
Hubby tried their oxtail stew. It came with a few pieces of oxtail but not as generous as the other divey restaurant across the street with a scant amt. of carrots. 
We tried their Hung Tao Yee won ton soup which arrived with 10 fried won tons in the broth with a few pieces of mushroom, chopped BBQ pork. It wasn't bad but I think this dish is better at 8 Immortals restaurant in the Sunset Dist. 
Prices are a bargain here for the amt. of food you get but it's not gourmet standards.
If you're hungry, it will settle the hunger pangs.

The place is larger than it looks from the street level but how can you tell from just peering down a flight of stairs from the street level.  How do they keep the rain and flooding street waters out of that place?
author: Ry T.

description: Typical Chinese food dishes. We ordered the set menu of $158 and was able to feed 14 people.  Good size portions on all dishes.  The waiter was able to translate the dishes into English for us since we do not read Chinese.  Food was not to salty and had great flavor.  Not the cleanest restaurant, but I think typical Chinatown restaurant.  Good service and good food.  Would eat there again.
author: Em D.

description:
After strolling around Chinatown and contemplating which Chinese restaurant to lunch at, we stumbled upon this little......basement .. mainly due to the tongue twister-like name.

For two, we ordered the Kung Pao Chicken and the Prawn Won Ton soup, both dishes ranging from $5 each. I also asked for an extra plate to share our meals, but the waiter quickly dodged me so I wasn't sure if he even heard my request. Don't expect much service, especially if you don't speak Chinese.

He came back with chopsticks and forks, exclaiming: " I don know if you guy need da chop stix or da fork, so I bring you guy both. " I am NOT chop stick illiterate even if I ordered in English! But I guess the waiter was concerned about our Asian dining etiquette skills.

Mediocre food, decent portions, affordable prices, stereotypical Chinatown bathroom (abominable), and a little less than average service if you don't speak Chinese in a Chinese restaurant.
author: Christine L.

description: A good place to eat for low price, but don't expect fancy stuff. It has the feel of an authentic Chinese place, at least if we look at the average customer and the employees. The service was satisfactory.
author: Marcos G.

description:
We are family of 10. Two parents and kids ranging from 16 years old down to two years old. This place was exactly what we were looking for! I wanted a place that had food that was different from anything you could get back home in Arizona. Hopefully, something better than you would get back home. But not something so different but the kids hated-has the mistake last year when we got dim sum in Chinatown and the kids simply stared at the food. 

We went on Christmas Day. It was full. The place was full. Lana served us and was not only friendly but spoke English - a problem we had last year in chinatown when nobody could help us at all. I'm not blaming the other restaurant's employees. We are the visitors in Chinatown. Still, for someone who only speaks English and goes into a restaurant is still nice having someone who speaks perfect English you can explain everything that you are ordering. Then again, the menu looked so close to what we are used to I could've probably handled this alone. Having said that, while a lot of the names are similar to menu items you see in Chinese restaurants across the country, enough was different and all of it was great. 

We ordered about 7 dishes. Liked everything. Sautéed scallops were great. The almond chicken was as well. My six year old liked it so much she said she is going to move here!
author: Mark B.

description: Food's great. I like the basement type restaurants. Was quiet during off hours. Extremely busy during dinner time. Cheap too. Nice people.
author: Andrew Z.

description: This little mom and pops restaurant is definitely gets the most value out of your money. Most of the items are around 5-8 dollars. I love their rice plates because it's has so much flavor and makes me feel right at home. Most of these restaurants in Chinatown aren't as good as this one. I highly recommend this restaurant to everyone.
author: Alvin L.

description: Value for money. I ordered its ginger crab. It was super fresh and tasty!
author: Elaine Z.

description: This place was pretty decent. Pricing good, service good, food okay. It's just that the food was very salty. Everything I ate needed a chug of tea. I'm also upset that they didn't let me take home my leftover rice. Weird.
author: Diana T.

description:
Ate here with my 15 year old daughter, she does not like Chinese food....she thought it was "really good".

We didn't eat anything exciting - Chicken Fried Rice, Chicken Chow Mein and Chicken Chop Suey.

I thought it was great!

Waitress was really nice!!!!

Would eat here again!!!!
author: Bryan U.

description: Interesting, I just read the reviews "after" chancing this place while in Chinatown a few weeks ago for a late lunch.  We were like the only ones in there.  Yes, a bit sketchy as it is "downstairs."  The food is delicious (except the egg rolls were horrid), plentiful, and inexpensive.  Service was good too.  Glad we stumbled upon this place.  I was in Chinatown in NYC the other night and the food at New Woey  was just as good and less $.
author: Rhona P.

description: Terrific food! Well worth the low price. Can't wait to go back.
author: Jon B.

description: Dirty and rude ! I Found a long hair in my Chop Suey!   Rude  staff. Don't bother. I hope I don't get sick
author: Stash P.

description:
4.75 star but what the heck, FIVE STARS

I thought this joint was going to be a total tourist trap (being on the corner of Grant and Jackson in Chinatown.) It was not.

We started off with complimentary soup, just a good broth, nothing fancy, just very homey. 

We tried the quail, it's only $2.50, good for 2 people to try if you have never had quail before. We then proceeded with braised squab, it is a fancy word for pigeon. Don't worry, it is cage raised, not the ones you find foraging food on the street. It had much more meat than I thought. We then finished off our dinner with steamed fish and ong choy. You can not go wrong there.

They changed our plates halfway through dinner because they were full of bones from the quail and squab. That only happens at high end Chinese restaurants. That scored a few extra points with me.

We received a complimentary dessert. I saw a few other tables getting fortune cookies but I think we got the traditional Hong Kong dessert due to our choice of order.

They are getting a few extra points because I saw a waiter brining out snail. SNAIL?!!? Hellls yeah YO! I am mos def coming back for that dish.

If you want typical shiny greasy Chinese American food, such as lemon chicken or sweet and sour pork, save the restaurant their dignity and go elsewhere. 

The food is more on the spectrum of traditional Chinese.
author: Tony N.

description: Great Chinese food at amazing prices. Got the cod and tender greens (bok choy) meal for just under $6. Also got the sea turtle soup special. They also have complementary soup, which is excellent.
author: Andrew A.

description: Mixed within many other restaurant choices this is a welcomed gem.  Delicious and yummy with ridiculous low lunch prices.  The menu includes the expected Chinese choices and some with a twist but no surprises.  My 8 year old even tried and loved the Chinese broccoli, Hubby thought it was to die for! The Mongolian was my favorite.  Very nice courteous service.  I'll be adding this to my "regular" list.
author: Mirta G.

description: Lunch with Dad. Classic traditional Cantonese food. Not fancy but good. Wonton noodle soup and rice dishes.
author: Chris L.

description: The underground local's restaurant. Old school, great food. Don't expect much in terms of decor or ambiance, but the food is great. Menus are in Chinese and English, specials on the wall Chinese only. They always serve soup right before the meal, complimentary. Not very many places do that anymore. Go with a group so you can order a bunch of dishes to try. I would come back multiple times to try everything on the menu.
author: Kiki J.
