description: Worst customer  service  ever! I don't think have ever been treated with so much disrespect by an owner we went in we went in hoping to find delicious Chinese food in Chinatown however we were very disappointed with the plates that we received the meat smelled like it was old and when we said we didn't like it the owner to rudely saying that if he had to refund all the food that people didn't like he would not have any money or a business so basically order at your own peril and if something in your order goes wrong don't expect this restaurant to fix it for you worst experience ever!
author: Enrique R.

description: The world's slowest service and the restaurant was only half full. Not sure what they are doing in the kitchen but to wait 45 min for a simple plate of beef ho fun is pretty ridiculous. Oh, the person next to me decided to leave without his food for the same reason.
author: Tina S.

description: I was going to give them a two star- because their scallop soup was decent. But I'd need to retract it after they failed to serve the correct items in semi decency.  I ordered the sparerib green pepper with flat noddle, and they heard wrong. They served  me beef/ green pepper with flat noddle. They lady took it back graciously, and returned with PICKED out beef ( not all) cooked some spareribs and re-cooked our noddles. It tasted like mr. Hanky! Omg!  Since we left the disgusting dish untouched, when i asked for the check the waiter brought the check, he charged my card, and stood behind me staring at how much tips i would give them. He totally made me uncomfortable, and i probably gave them more than they deserved. Definitely NOT EVER coming back again or recommending this place to anyone!
author: Monika T.

description:
We were just thinking/laughing about this place the other day even though it has been over a year and a half since we have been here (read never coming back)

Not only did we end up with a beetle alive and swimming in our food (we were nice about this, things happen) we also got screwed over by the waiter!

We have never been so ripped off by a restaurant before.  I think everyone's reviews would be lower if they looked at their bill and added up what they ordered.  The overcharged us $30 on a $40 check.  When i asked the waiter he told me it was his tip... WTF  Come on, that is way sketchy!?! Maybe they don't do that for fellow Asian customers because Im sure no one would eat there
author: melisa w.

description:
Cheap Chinese food. Delicious? Yes. Authentic? Pretty much. 

Good service? NO.

The food tasted pretty good. It wasn't the best Chinese food I've tasted, but the soup, stir fry vegetables, and salt and pepper shrimps sure hit the spot. But I wouldn't come here again. Let me tell you about my experience during ONE dine-in.

Now, don't expect spectacular service when you're in an authentic Chinese restaurant. Call yourself lucky if they greet you. The waitresses won't smile at you, but they will serve soup for you. What made this restaurant's service worse than other Chinese restaurants?

First of all, they accidentally placed the wrong dish on our table. We ordered a "meal set" with this dish, but apparently the "meal set" only includes a smaller portion of the particular dish. We started to eat from this dish, and the waiter rudely grabbed the dish from us without saying anything. He didn't apologize or explain his action. We only understood what was going on when they placed the same dish with a smaller portion back on our table. And they still didn't apologize or even speak to us. Rude.

While we were eating, we heard screaming. Two ladies were yelling at each other in Chinese; one was a worker, the other was a customer. Apparently, the customer reserved a table, but the worker accidentally seated tourists at this table. The tourists looked confused during the loud argument. The worker finally caved in and told the tourists that the table was reserved. The tourists left angrily. No one could blame them.

As if that wasn't bad enough, the workers found out that a table needed extra chairs. One waitress walked to an occupied table and grabbed a chair without communicating to the customers who were sitting at the table. A nice gesture or a simple "excuse me" would've been adequate, but the waitress didn't even bother to look at the customers when she grabbed the chair.

All this drama within an hour. You know what they say in baseball. Three strikes- and you're OUT! 

If you're looking for cheap Chinese food, and if you're only thinking of dining in and leaving instantly, sure, come here by all means. But if you're not, STEER CLEAR AT ALL COSTS. You've been warned. I'm out.
author: Dana S.

description:
The name alone get big points from me. I've had this place bookmarked for the longest time because of that and today, my friend who lives near it, took me there because he likes it that much. I suppose it was a fortuitous day.

Anyway, you get rice and soup with your dishes. The rice was good and the soup had lots of good stuff in it. We ordered the pork spare ribs and they were nicely fried. Some pieces were huge and fatty. The salt and pepper flounder was really good too, though perhaps a little too much salt. The chicken with mushrooms mellowed it out. It was in a savory sauce that wasn't goopy. Anyway, definitely worth it and it was just the right portion too. It's good and cheap:

LUNCH DEALS!! $4-5 PLATES!

Warning: The restroom light is outside the restroom. I stood in that little stall of a restroom for the longest time looking for a switch and not finding it, but eventually figured out the switch outside the door was it. And yes, it is a typical Chinatown restroom.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
As soon as I walked into the restaurant it had the authentic chinese food feel to it so I was pretty excited to try it out. When I walked in though the server just stared at me from a chair across the room, I didn't know if I was supposed to just pick a table or wait to be seated. Finally after a couple minutes he looks to the woman in charge who was frantically scurrying around and points to us lazily and she helps us out. They weren't very busy at all, only 4 tables were occupied including my friend and I, however they were clearly overwhelmed. It took them 15 minutes after giving us a menu to ever come check on us or anything, however a positive is that the food came out pretty quickly! Well most of it...they brought all three dishes at different times, and it felt more like I was having a three course meal which was a bit of a bummer. They also never brought our water and took another 10 minutes after we finished to get us the check. 

The food, however, was quite delicious. We went with sweet and sour pork, pork egg foo young and cashew nut chicken. It was all very tasty and had authenticity for sure (sweet and sour sauce was amazing, very nice texture-not too thick but not too runny). They had only two people waiting tables, one of which just seemed a bit lost the whole time we were in there, and were definitely overwhelmed. The experience overall was average, service was very poor, but the food was of good quality. I would recommend if you're in China town, but it's not worth any sort of an extra trip to get there and they REALLY need to address their service issues. But if you don't mind waiting awhile, then head over there because the food was pretty good.
author: Dan K.

description: First thing I expect when I come in to any Oriental Restaurant is the terrible service, but coming to this place here the waitress who doesn't speak English might I add has the most lousy customer service I have ever experienced.  She even had the nerve to ask for a full tip after I paid.  I told her "I get half service, you get half tip".  The gentleman on the other hand was okay but the older waitress lady is just something else.  The reason I give this place two stars is for the food and for the price.  You can get a decent size plate of food for about $5 which is quite nice.  I heard the Salt and Pepper Chicken was all the rave here and that was the only I really came to this restaurant.  After trying the chicken, it was quite tasty and greasy like I expected it but nonetheless it was very flavorful.  As for the kung pao beef dish it came out piping hot as well, but the flavor was pretty generic but better than any Panda Express by my standards.  If you're hungry and looking for food on the cheap this is a good place to go, but if you're looking for great service forget about it, it isn't going to happen.
author: Timothy T.

description:
Good for tourist...Great for local.

****Wo choy menu then add some noodles.
Pork hash with salt fish...Chinese Spinach...westlake soup
...comfort style foods.
author: Cee G.

description: Good food. Nothing spectacular but not bad. The service was a bit slow. Chop Suey was very tasty. I ordered the hot and sour soup and it was a bit bland for my taste.  Egg rolls were ok. There were many local Chinese people eating lunch at the bar area.
author: Ali F.

description:
I was really presently surprised when I walked in here! I hear "hole-in-the-wall" and I thought it was going to be a dump. But it's nothing of the sort. Sure, you have to walk down some stairs to get there, but then it's a normal restaurant. 

This place was great. The food was good and the prices were good. Everything my family ordered was delicious. From the beef been curd to the Shanghai style noodles, to the stuffed eggplant to the roasted duck. It was all delicious. 5 people ate themselves silly (4 dishes and soup) and paid $40. It was great. 

The food is flavorful, well priced, and good. What else can you want?
author: Mariko F.

description: Despite the name and basement location, the New Gooey, as I call it, has well done, healthy C-town C-food. Recommend the pea shoots and seafood dishes. Chefs may be eating their own cooking at the table next to you. I usually hit other Chinatown spots for lunch due to their super cheap specials, but this is my go to dinner spot. Lots of locals, but a surprising number of tourists as well.
author: Nick C.

description: You can tell food is good here cause it's one of those hard to find spots when you walk down the stairs you find packed with people. Had the spicy eggplant clay pot, tasted great.
author: Adriano C.

description:
My All Time FAV Chinese place in the city

Discovered in 09, have brought back everyone i know to this place, 

sometimes i dont want to rate it highly just because i dont want people aka "hipsters" coming, thinking theyre all cool going to some hole in the wall in china town. psh get over yourselves 

love the garlic chicken clay pot yum yum yum 
i always get soup, love the broths. 

mongolian beef mmm, and the chicken wings. 

and chow mein you can never go wrong. 

and the tea is really good, not watered down or flavorless. 

and im secretly best friends with the two owners (business partners not couple)
author: Amien P.

description:
I first came to this location for lunch back in....1973! Gads! A friend who lived in SF took me. The look from the street, deep in the heart of Chinatown, was not exactly appealing. Going down a half flight of stairs lent a whole 'nother level of oddness, the glass and aluminum wall more odd, and the big room with lots of tables and a long counter.

It hasn't changed much in looks since then.

Luckily, the food has continued to be wonderful and sometimes better still. I've tried just about everything that I can read in English, and the servers will offer good suggestions. Enjoy!
author: William M.

description: Best deal in town. Delicious variety of lunches. I had the curry beef stew over pan fried noodles. Yummy! I also had hong tou yee fu won ton...which is deep fried won tons in soup..that's my old time favorite and comfort food.
author: j. l.

description:
Pretty good food, all in all. My dining companion and I had the Szechuan Family Dinner and enjoyed every bite.

As at least one other reviewer mentioned, they add your tip to your check. More troubling, they don't seem to tell you this, in person, ANYWHERE ON THE MENU, or on your check (which still has an empty line for tip)--so if my friend hadn't thought to check, we would have paid them a handsome 40% tip. A little dodgy, right?
author: Joel S.

description: Do not come here ever! The service is beyond bad, the dinning era is dirty, the food is nasty! Really regretted to come here. And when I was paying the bill the cashier, he yelled at me about the credit card limit but I was using a debit card... he didn't let me use my card either way and I had to get cash from a ATM nearby... Just Don't Wast Your Time And Money Here!!! Trust Me!!!
author: Alex Y.

description:
Went here on a Sunday for a late lunch and the experience was terrible. 

- When ordering, the waiter was hard to understand even though he knew English and just confused us on how rice was ordered with the dishes. 
- There was a staff person sitting at a table prepping a pile of vegetables on one of the tables. Some random Caucasian lady joined the man at the table and started helping him. Then she started obnoxiously yelling at other patrons to come help. Very unprofessional and annoying. That lady was either drunk, on drugs, or just super inconsiderate of customers who want to eat in peace. And the restaurant staff didn't do anything about it.
- The beef chow mein was delicious. Other meat dishes we ordered were OK (sweet and sour chicken & honey walnut shrimp). 
- While my boyfriend was using the restroom, someone rudely pounded on the door and actually bashed in the restroom door while he was in there yelling that the room was occupied. When the boyfriend came out to complain to management, they did not understand or just ignored him. Meaning they didn't do anything to make the situation better. 
- I went with a party of five. When the bill came out, they tacked on 18% tip without even telling us. Yes, the bill was all in chinese and we could not understand all the charges. Luckily, we asked a waiter to come and explain everything. Was pretty pissed off that the 18% was tacked on because this place did NOT deserve such a tip and my party was 5 not the usual 6. I regret paying the tip, but we just paid and quickly got the f*ck out of there.

NEVER COMING BACK.
author: AP H.

description: The server might be a little grumpy, but no need to worry about the good, good portion and delicious as expected. Good value and has free WiFi。
author: Liang Z.

description: I love this place best food in SF besides Clement St. XD cheap food and their Singapore Noodle is better than how I make it. XD 1934 so old.
author: Michael W.

description:
I've been going here for lunch on Saturdays for years, and it's still as good as the days when I was a kid. It's definitely sketchy, as you have to walk down this steep flight of stairs before you get into the restaurant. But once you're in the door, it's your typical Chinese joint.

Their rice plates are probably the best bargain. I mean, they feed you well here with a decent amount of rice and entree for around $5. Someone in my family usually orders the Salted Fish and Chicken Fried Rice. Take a look at my photo. It's a ton of food on the plate! But it's not a ton of junk. There's some serious flavor in it, without too much grease.

"Tong Lok" (NWLG's name in Chinese) is one of my go-to spots in SF Chinatown. The food's always consistent and cheap. Can't go wrong with that!
author: Diana C.

description:
First off, what If I was disabled?? They don't have wheel chair access, second, when we got our tea and I poured it, there was a hair.. Totally gross! Third, our hot and sour soup had chunks of saltiness in it. Fourth, we got our food w/o our fried rice.. When it came, we were almost halfway done w/o the rice bc we were hungry. Fifth, the Mosquitos ate up my legs!!! Not cool!!

Lastly, our food and drinks only came out to $28.50 w/o tax.. Please tell me how it came out to $34.90? According to everyone, they apparently add tip to the bill w/o your consent.. So guess what? No tip for them...

Food was overall salty and I will not recommend them to anyone.  As we were walking out, the lady shrugged her head and gave me a dirty look.. Probably bc we didn't give more tip than the tip they so kindly added themselves for two people.. Is that even legal?
author: Valerie B.

description:
A solid Chinese food spot w/ fast and friendly service. 

My friends and I visited for dinner Sat. night, and we enjoyed a variety of flavorful and quickly cooked meals. I would say the best is the pan fried flounder because of the flavorful soy sauce mixture that's at the base of the plate, and the perfectly fried fish. The next favorite was the pork clay pot.. not as good as the ones made at similar restaurants in LA IE- Guangzhou Palace in Rowland Heights, but still fine. Pork fried rice was decent. And my little nitpicking about Chinese restaurants are the teas they serve, if they do. This place serves strong ass Jasmine tea, and they refill it without you asking, just keep the tea cover open, they'll get the hint.. 

I WILL be back for more..
author: Thomas L.

description: This cheap Chinese has become my favorite Chinatown stop. Excellent rice plates for lunch, many under $5, I recommend beef with tomato, Chinese broccoli chicken, the Singapore noodles have just the right amount of curry and we can't miss the seafood combination. Service is fast, sometimes I call ahead and the food is waiting when I get there. The best value for the money in Chinstown.  The owners are VERY nice people.  This is a regular place for me, I'm never disappointed in the price, service or food.
author: Chris K.

description:
5 stars because it IS as good as it gets for the price.

After 2 hours of running around in China town looking for airsoft guns for my boyfriend's inner child, we came here (restaurant name I can't pronounce) to some cheap yummy chinese food.

You go down some stairs into the basement, the ceilings are low, the tables are closely set up to each other, living seafood swimming in the fish tank and there's a whole wall of chinese writings at the bar. 

We ordered so much food between the 3 of us. We got the hot and sour soup, which was fantastic. It was the small size but I got 7+ cups out of it. We got some chow mein, fried rice, spicy mongolian beef, mushroom chicken, lotus chicken, and another beef dish. Everything was good. 

The best thing was when our japanese friend ate the whole fortune cookie without taking out the paper because he's never seen it before. 

The service was nice, the food was good, pricing was awesome, it really is as good as it gets!
author: Erica L.

description:
This place is terrible. First off you need to go downstairs to the dining area. The place looks like one of those old school places where a person could get shot at any time. If you are a non Chinese speaker you are going to have a terrible time there. Communication was hard even seating was a difficult process. 

So anyways on to my dining experience. We had to flag down someone to take our order because we were practically being ignored. They knew we were non Chinese speaking so we got ignored even more, how rude. People who were Chinese were being greeted a lot better as they were coming in. Their orders were being taken even faster. But that's not what irked me the most. What irked me the most was that people who came after us got their food faster than we did despite the fact that we ordered before them. It wasn't only one table either, it was like 5 tables after we came in before we finally got our food. Another side note that isn't such a big deal, they gave us forks because we didn't speak Mandarin or Cantonese, but we were Asian. 

On to the food. Yeah it was nothing special, ordered some chow fun, some sweet and sour pork and some won ton soup. It was something you would expect for the price. The won tons had some bone in it, not a pleasant experience chewing on that. 

After that we again waited so long for our bill that I had to go to the counter to pay, while I saw others getting treated differently. 

In summary, do not come here unless you speak Mandarin or Cantonese, or come here with someone who already does, this place is terrible.
author: Tako B.

description: I wish i could give this place 0 stars. For one, when we walked in we were pretty much blatantly disregarded and had to ASK if we could have a table.When we sat down at the table it was dirty, and the cups that they gave us for tea were also dirty.  Once we were finally seated we waited for about 15 minutes before anyone even came up and asked if we'd like drinks or liked to order. We ordered a coca cola,green onion fried rice, fried wontons and sweet and sour pork. The wontons arrived first and they were good. The fried rice arrived second and we did not like it. We hadn't realized that there was scallops in it and we didn't like the fishiness to it. When the sweet and sour pork arrived we told our waiter that we didn't like the rice and asked if we could return it to the kitchen to get something else and he said NO. He said he didn't care if we didn't like it or not we still had to pay for it. We asked him what he does when a customer isn't satisfied and he just shrugged and said we still have to pay for something that we took ONE bite of and didn't like. Let's just say I will NEVER be coming back to this restaurant. WORST customer service ever.
author: Bre S.

description:
I work in the area, and this restaurant with a, well, funny name is rapidly becoming one of my favorites.

Food is decent, authentic Cantonese, but priced remarkably well--that's what earns it the fourth star. I prefer to do takeout, which costs slightly more than the menu price, but not much. Portion are large, again, huge value for your money.

The Tung Lok special chow mein was excellent, with a smorgasbord of ingredients. So was the wonton soup. I'll have to add more as I go through the menu.
author: Jan J.

description: Not for the faint of heart. This menu serves the tourists and the community. So don't get ethno-phobic. Walk down those stairs and have a great meal. The food is solid (minus egg rolls). It's a nice change because you will see a nice mix a tourist and locals. And if the locals eat here you know they've got the goods. And they do.
author: Michelle A.

description:
For good chinese food. COME HERE. I like coming here for casual occasions, especially when I'm craving real chinese food. A lot of the places in Chinatown now are all americanized and filled with tourists who don't know what real Chinese food is and those restaurants end up catering to those customers!

Anyways... order the fresh sauteed vegetables that are currently in season, braised tofu, braised tofu and peppers. I'm not sure what else I can recommend, but just look at the table and order what they got.
author: Jackie M.

description:
Just by reading the name of this place makea me believe I'm fluent in Cantonese.  I would hope it means New Cheap Bad Food Restaurant cause that is exactly what I experienced.  

Being the stupid tourist, I assumed Cantonese food would be very good in the Godfather of all Chinatowns. Eek!  Methinks not.  The prices seemed a good bang for the buck so we decided to get the family dinner for 4.  

It is hard when you go to a Chinese restaurant with non-pork eaters becaues Chinese pork dishes are usually a great.  Since the meal for 4 had so much pork going on, we asked the waitress to switch for beef instead of pork or chicken except for the almond chicken.  

The first disaster started when she switched the menu's soup to egg drop soup for some reason.  I think the cook was too lazy to cook the Won Tons since some of his buddies were waiting for him to have some drinks.  I happen to HATE eggs, yes it's weird, I know but the amount of egg in this soup was so exterme I defenitely passed on that.  My friends did not seem to have a problem with that so I didn't hesitate to spoil their appetizer.  The rest of the orders the waitress served it all wrong.  She served us nothing BUT chicken.... She looked pretty tired and annoyed already so we decided not to bother her and just give all that chicken some munchin'.  Flavorless, greasy, cheap and definitely not what I expected from Chinatown.... disappointing.  Oh yeah, don't go to the restroom in this restaurant, its pretty filthy.

The best part was when one family started fighting and the drunk table got involved and the whole restaurant was in shock.  I wish I had subtitles for this part cause it was the only thing worth the $40 something we spent...
author: Camilo G.

description:
As expected, foreigners are a little hesitant about walking down a creepy looking staircase into a dimly-lit room where who-knows-what goes on. (There were only Chinese people inside when I walked in.)

However.... when your in Chinatown its a bit different, as a lot of the stores and restaurants seem to be "downstairs" or have a downstairs compartment. 

I think one of the greatest (and possibly most noteworthy) things about this restaurant is how cheap the lunch meals are!  Just $4-5 bucks!!!  I mean, you can't even get Chinese food that cheap at Panda Express!  (And that isn't even "real" Chinese food).  I ordered the sweet & sour pork with rice plate, and I'm glad to say that it was very tasty. 

But WHY did I take away one star you ask?

Plainly put, the restroom was -filthy-!  And it smelled like someone died in there!  I understand that they want to spend most of their time/energy on cooking Chinese food, but I'm sure the cooks use that same restroom. And if his hands are touching nasty things in there, I DEFINITELY wouldn't want his hands in my food.
author: Mike K.

description:
You are in the heart of Chinatown surrounded by Chinese tourist shops and marginal tourist restaurants. Where do you go without busting your wallet for some barely adequate Chinese food? 

Try this place.
.
For a place that is a HITW, the food is very good!

We were in that awful in between time of Not Lunch and Not Dinner of 3:30 and light-headed from lack of food. After Yelping a number of larger restaurants on Grant Street (most all of them 2 stars), we stumbled on this near corner place that was open!

There is little to no ambiance to speak of, and the place has a grim feel to it.

The service is OK but the food was honestly the draw here. Not expensive but honestly good. The selection is small and trending toward the American-style Chinese end of the spectrum, serving Cantonese and Sichuan style food. Thank goodness it did not taste that way. :)

We had the Beef Chow Fun and the Tong Luk Special Chow Mein with the Hong Kong style crispy noodles (for a buck extra).

There was nothing to complain about at all: 

The Beef Chow Fun was excellent, not greasy, the beef was tender, and the portion was generous.

Same for the Special: lots of freshly perfectly prepared meats (squid, shrimp, scallops, BBQ pork, chicken), Shitake mushrooms, and baby bok choy over crisp pan fried noodles with a nice Hong Kong style brown sauce.

All this & tea for under $20 (with tip), which in this touristy part of Chinatown is a great bargain.
author: Glenn H.

description:
How do you even read the name of this place in English? It is like a tongue twister. I walked down the stairs into NWLGR which is situated beneath ground level and it was like I stepped into a time machine. I am pretty sure nothing in here has changed since 1970 from clocks to wall decorations.

Now for the food. Very cheap and good for authentic Chinese food. If you want simple Chinese food, this is a great spot to be. You get a big bowl of complimentary house soup which is a meal in itself and a couple things and you can feed 2 for a little less than $15. I loved the beef chow fun and pork and oysters clay pot, reminded me of food I ate growing up. Don't expect much service, just affordable, fast food.
author: Ed L.

description: The best snails in black bean sauce EVER!  The salt & pepper chicken wings and braised quail was awesome too.  The place is non-pretentious, reasonably priced, and family atmosphere.  I will definitely woey loy next time as the name says.
author: Diana W.

description: A great restaurant, but don't be deceived by the outside appearance.. It literally looks like a hole in the ground with descending stairs into a cave.. but to only find a decent restaurant. The waiter we had was extremely friendly and nice, and the food was excellent. I highly recommend the Szechuan Tofu, it taste as good as it looked. I also went with some fellow yelpers, and we kind of ate off of each others plate, and the other food was also very fantastic!!  Overall good restaurant and will return the next time I'm in China Town.
author: Simon W.

description:
Their prices aren't too bad but I felt the dishes I had were quite bland and lacked seasonings. 

The waiters were nice but some cooks at the restaurant seemed to be getting into drama in front of people eating in the restaurant. They were throwing boxes down their front stairs causing a ruckus. 

I did appreciate the fortune cookies at the end of the meal, sometimes they are forgotten.
author: Maya S.

description: It's one of the places that my family been going to since the 2000s. Their food all have great "wok hei" and I'm continually impressed by their consistency.
author: William W.

description: Awesome food. Every meal comes with a free glass of tea. I got the Mongolian beef with rice and wonton soup per my waiters recommendation. Very fast service and the food tasted excellent.
author: Paul P.

description:
The food is good, but the waiter asked and expected more tip.  This is the ultimate insult.  I believe I am a reasonable tipper - I will  tip EXCESSIVELY and little when called for.

The fact that I will adamantly not return brings this to a 1 star.
author: Betty V.

description:
This restaurant is a hidden gem, don't let the appearance fool you, the foods amazing  & a great deal! Once you get seated and start enjoying the amazing hot & sour soup, some of the hot pots & excellent noodles you will be in Chinese food heaven! 
This was a great spot to find on my day out n china town and I will probably be back!
author: Harrison G.

description:
when you are broke this is a great restaurant to just get full plus take to go.
$5.99 for beef chow fun.  (not really good though)
$6.99 for peking style spear rib. (sauce is good, meat is not good quality, lots of fat)
author: Rina C.

description: Came with a regular who ordered in Chinese. Food was awesome, presentation authentic, prices outstanding. (From what I understand the English and Chinese names posted out front are like totally divergent.) I'll be back.
author: Zake S.

description: We went to this restaurant on recommendation from some locals. The Duck Wonton Soup was amazing, the fried rice was very good and the prices were great. It was a nice change from the touristy restaurants in Chinatown.
author: Michael B.

description: This might not be a five star Chinese diner but service was sincere. Owners tried their best to serve every table with patience and sincerity . Dishes were surprisingly yummy and close to authentic! Given the fact that it is Chinese food in USA, it's taste is very well pretty close! If clueless what to order, feel free to ask the owners for recommendations!
author: Tristen N.

description:
stumbled across this after a ball game awhile ago

was on my own and sat at the counter, ordered tea, an enormous bowl of hot and sour soup, chili squid, chicken and vegetables and egg fried rice

everything was piping hot, fresh, delicious and plentifull, and came to around $20

obviously ordered way too much, so got them to box some rice and squid for my friend back home, and when he ate it 2 hours later, the squid was just as crunchy and tender as when fresh

definitely my fav chinese i've come across
author: Dan B.

description: This place is small and tucked away, but has a nice ambiance. There is room for a few groups of 8-10, as well as tables for 4.  We had settled in and ordered when suddenly our plans changed.  They changed our order to go, but still provided good service.  The food was really good!  Can't wait to go back next time we are in the city!
author: Marlene H.

description:
You know a Chinese restaurant has to be 4+ Yelp stars when nearly half the customers are non-Chinese AND its located in the basement. This is one of those "I can't believe how many times I've been to Chinatown and never even considered this place?!?!?".

The food is absolutely delicious and almost on par with Koi Palace. However, what really makes this better than Koi is the value. For $228 you can get a 10 person meal complete with Shark's Fin soup and enough food to make even Kobayashi satisfied.



**Words of wisdom: DO NOT to eat to the point where you need to #2. The stall is so small that, while you're doing the dreaded, your knees literally touch the door.
author: leland k.

description:
Due to my ever small budget , eating in the FiDi was a negative.

So thus my rule of thumb, must grab lunches outside a 5 blk radius of my office.  Doesn't really leave me with much options, but I can always find something yummy in Chinatown.

The last time I was here, was probably 5 years ago, for a family dinner, so I decided to check it out for some lunch specials.

Walked down some scary steps (only scary cus I'm notoriously clumsy), through a door and was approached by a very friendly man, (who appeared to be the owner because he wasnt wearing a black waiter outfit like the others), asked what I wanted.

I searched their lengthy lunch specials.. but what caught my eye was:

Fu Kien Fried Rice (no its not pronounced F$%king Fried Rice but it sure sounds like it!):
Chicken fried rice, topped with some gravy business that contains, shrimp, scallops, mushrooms, and greens. 

I wanted some veggie/tofu side, so I asked the "owner" what he recommended.  He said the "Braised Tofu, add vegetables". Even though I'm very particular about tofu, I really couldnt ask for specifics cus my Chinese is horribly limited. So I said OK.

15 minutes later.....and $17.00 less I had TWO HUGE togo containers of food + 2 containers of the daily soup (total plus)!

Soup was simple but flavorful, good to warm the tummy up for some more food.

Fu Kien Fried Rice= GOEY in a good way! Enough gravy to make sure all parts of the fried rice has a bit of it, but not so much where it was drowned. TONS of scallops and shrimp.

Braised Tofu w/Veggies = TOFU WAS THE BOMB! It was the super soft tofu, that tasted like it was freshly made. All up in a gravy sauce with some bok choy.  To be honest....the gravy kinda tasted the same as the one on my fried rice..but I didn't care cus the tofu was soo good!

Me and my coworker ate until our tummies was given us super muffintop, and there was still half left of each order! Great bang for $17 and enough to feed 4!
author: Deanna T.

description:
Long Pong Duck Dong?

I keed, I keed.  Literal whole in the wall/ground?  Sketch entrance, stairwell into the unknown.  But downstairs you find your average, quaint family style Chinese food restaurant.

Great lunch specials.  I had Chicken Chowmein for just $4.99.  FO NINETY NINE!  Don't be scared away by the entrance, this is most definitely a place worth popping in, even if just for once.

Although this place didn't completely knock my socks off and demanded my never faltering allegance, I would have no problem coming back.  But with everything there is out there in Chinatown, it might not be right away.
author: Chelsea C.

description:
It can get REALLY crowded in this small restaurant during lunch hours and on weekends during dinnertime, so be prepared to cozy up with the people around you at the tiny tables.  You have to walk down a steep flight of stairs to get to the "underground" restaurant, so be sure to watch your step!  

The food at New Woey Loy Goey is very affordable, the portions are large, and none of the dishes are dripping in oil - a big plus for me. The waitstaff at New Woey Loy Goey are all pretty friendly and are willing to accommodate most special requests (taking the meat out of specific dishes, etc.).  There's usually a good mix of Chinese and non-Chinese people in the restaurant, so it's not a big deal if you want to eat at this restaurant and don't speak Chinese.

You can also call their phone number and place take-out orders for their noodles or rice combos. They are extremely quick with orders (the food will usually be ready in 15-20 minutes), and you get a HUGE amount of food (enough to feed 2-3 people easily) for very little money - most lunch specials are around $5. They serve pretty above-average Chinese food at a very affordable price! You also get a big cup of mystery "soup of the day" with your take-out orders.
author: Karen L.

description:
TYPICAL Chinese food place. The food is alright (I've only been here for dinner) the service is okay, but I think the prices are pretty cheap? I'm sure I'll be back with my loud out-towner relatives. Oh joy.
But at least it's pretty convenient for all the tourist to pop in and enjoy some decent cheap Chinese food.
author: Irene L.

description:
This place has E-mein just the way I like it. Not too greasy, not too salty, and has a good variety of meats and veggies. 

Its the old school style of restaurant where the place is in the basement of a building. This may be a different concept for most westerners, but its common in Asian cultures. There's some cultural enlightenment for you Mr./Ms. Yelp Reader. 

Affordable, delicious and can account for large groups, this place is good for lunch and dinner. The only set back is there is no elevator service for people who use wheelchair.
author: Jason C. J.

description:
Living in North Beach and having Chinatown right down the block is so awesome.  It has some of the best "hole in the wall" restaurants in the city.  However, not all are created equal...

GREAT DEAL + GREAT FOOD + GREAT SERVICE = 5 YELP STARS

This is my "Go To" spot in Chinatown.  The people are nice and for those who are don't speak Chinese, you'll have no problems ordering and asking questions.  The food is always good and fresh and at a great price.  I go there for lunch and get tea, soup and rock cod fish fillet/bock choy over rice for $5.50!!!!  

This is truly authentic food, one where you'll see locals going to.

SUGGESTED PLATE:  Tomato Beef Chowmein with Pan Fried Noodles - It is sooooooo good!  Be sure you request pan friend noodles.

Long name... Great restaurant!  Two thumbs up!
author: Aaron L.

description: This place is surprisingly decent and fairly inexpensive. Been here twice for dinner with a large group and ordered a variety of things (Asian style dishes and not the ones you find at more Americanized Chinese restaurants).
author: Ed T.

description:
My family and I had an extremely bad experience here.  The reason we chose to eat at this restaurant was because of my aunt who found good reviews on yelp and because this place offered parking validation for the local parking garage.

Our visit started off with us going in and asking if they were still serving lunch.  The gentleman who was seating us assured us that yes, they were still serving lunch.  Another gentleman came over to take our order.  Comes to find out, this gentleman told us that lunch prices ended at 2:30pm.  We bit the bullet and stayed and paid the dinner prices.

When our meal was over, my aunt asked to get her parking ticket validated.  The server told her he couldn't because the drawer where the stamp was was locked and the owner who had the key for the drawer was not there.  My aunt told him how disappointed she was and told him that the validation was why she came to the restaurant.  She then ask if she could have the cash worth for the 2 hours that the validation was worth.  He got defensive and got dramatic by showing us his empty pockets.  He told us he had no money to give us.  And pretty much he was arguing and yelling at us.

Then my father paid using a credit card.  The server came back and told us the credit card machine wasn't working.  My father told him he didn't have cash.  The server went back and tried again.  And miraculously it worked.

To wrap it up . . terrible service.  What kind of business argues and yells at their customers?  First, the staff was not on the same page about lunch and dinner times and prices.  Second, if they say they validate parking then they should be able to validate during the hours their business is open.  Third, don't try to be sneaky and say your "credit card machine is not working" so you can get cash instead.

My family will not be coming back here and we will be sure not to tell anyone else to come here either.
author: Rosely T.

description:
Even before we ate here, you would not have had to twist my arm to get me to move back to SF. The minced squab only made the idea even more appealing.  A superb mix of rich squab and spices just waiting to get wrapped up into lettuce.  I would have preferred Bibb/Boston lettuce to the iceberg they served - it made the squab taste too watered down.  I ended up just shoving it directly into my piehole (squab-hole?)

The server was extremely tolerant of the SSBB's white boy questions.  For someone who has spent so much time in Asia you'd think he'd know better than want to order chop suey.  But I digress.

The decor is unremarkable.  Lots of extended families were spinning the lazy Susans laden with all sorts of fantastic looking food, including a whole lobster at the table next to us.  It wasn't on the menu, perhaps one should ask for specials?

We also ordered mongolian beef and BBQ pork chow mein (white boys...).  The beef was good, not too greasy and corn-starchy.  The chow mein was ok.  The SSBB powered it down the next day for dinner, after it had had sat UNREFRIGERATED in the car for 10 hours and didn't die, so I guess that's saying something.  My smug lectures on food borne illness tend to fall on deaf ears with this guy.

So SF, will the squab's siren song lure me back?  We'll see, we'll see.
author: Kiki M.

description: I actually found the descending stairs into this restaurant really cool. The inside is a bit hole in the wall but everyone is quite nice. We ordered 5 dishes here and it all arrived to our table super fast. The food is DELICIOUS in generous portions and oh my goodness, SO CHEAP. It's such a steal that I almost feel awful that I paid so little, haha. They even gave us free soup and dessert since my family comes here so often... and honestly I can see why they come here so often. This place is great, give it a try!
author: Candy L.

description: Great place to eat!  We were recommended there by the people at the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie place and the whole family loved it.  Good prices & great food!
author: Angela M.

description:
I don't know how my dad finds these places but one day he suggested we try this place. Upon arrival, I was skeptical since the last couple basement Chinese restaurants I went to were...well...sorta gross AND the freaking sign said "chop suey". I have yet to eat decent food at a Chinese restaurant that advertises they serve chop suey.  Surprise! As I descended the steps (no elevator or stair-lift-thing for wheelchairs) the waitstaff was welcoming and the walls were clean and the tables were neatly arranged. There's still that slight grime that usually happens at Chinese restaurants but for being in a basement, this was nothing.

The food is good it is what is expected from a hole-in-the-wall restaurant - piping hot, fresh, full of flavor but not too salty, and not lacking in that hot, wok-sear flavor. Not to mention the portion sizes and the prices! Where else can you get a lunch that will make you loosen your belt for less than $5?!?!?! And just because this place is in the heart of Chinatown (now overrun with tourist traps) doesn't mean the locals don't eat here. My favorite dish is the beef and tofu (bean curd) lunch special. Believe it or not, I think this dish is hard to do well so I tend to use it as a measure of quality. 

Am I the only one to wonder why the Chinese name of this restaurant is so different than the English name??? Maybe they changed it and never bothered to order new menus and outdoor signage?
author: Vicki F.

description: Rats run in and out of the front door to the kitchen as you dine, while flies land on your food.  The place smells like a week old dead octopus inside of a bucket of stale sponges.  They overcharge you and add a gratuity (written in chinese) and do not inform you.  Get the chicken, i dare you.
author: Rob B.

description: This is my favorite place to eat in China Town. It's pretty hidden so most tourists simply walk right past it so it's primarily patronized by local residents. The prices are very reasonable and the service is fast. I find the food to be tasty and authentic. Great place to grab dinner if you can find it.
author: Dee G.

description: Food was alright. I've had better. Service is nothing special and bathrooms are pretty gross. I would probably pick a different spot if I had my choice again for lunch.
author: Jason P.

description: Classic, cheap, Chinese place--like someone's partially-finished basement. Had a hankering for wonton soup with BBQ pork and noodles. Good pork, so-so noodles & wontons, the broth wasn't complex enough--but it's tough to cook in an unfinished basement, non?
author: John I.

description:
seems like went downhill from my last time there ( 3 years ago).
and yes, be warned - they will upsale you to 10$ of fried rice and they will add more than generous tip in the bill.
author: foodie t.

description:
What does Harriet Tubman, Batman, and New Woey Loey Goey Restaurant (greatest restaurant name since this place http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/upAmDRVXPGBuGAotHRiNqA/l ) all have in common? No No No it has nothing to do with black people, all three have utilized and perfected the use of the "Underground." Harriet Tubman had the heralded "Underground Railroad." Batman had his secret "Underground" lair, and New Woey Loey Goey has its surprisingly stellar Chinese Restaurant!

Walking down New Woey Loey Goey Resturant it looked like any other Chinese Restaurant except for the bar seating they had on the left. I've never seen this kind of seating at a Chinese Restaurant and thought it was pretty awesome.The decor was pretty simple and the Restaurant itself was pretty empty (Went on a weekday around 2).

When I looked at the menu I almost fell out of my seat and yelled the only Chinese words I knew, Diew Lei Gah Mah Gah Hai! This place was cheap! I'm not talking about $10 for your meal including tip cheap, i'm talking about $5 for something really big and you over tipped kind of cheap! I mean there were literally items for 3 dollars! That is cheaper than the damn Toll Plaza! That's 11 quarters 2 dimes and a nickel...or 12 quarters! (shout out to Chappelle). This place was totally "Recession Friendly." 

Now with a meal costing less than a pair of shoelaces I somewhat lowered my standards for the quality and taste, once again New Woey Loey Goey Restaurant pleasantly surprised. Now don't get me wrong, the chef isn't going to be challenging Iron Chef Morimoto anytime soon, but the food was pretty good. Great amount of food and I would go as far as saying above average in the taste department.

You are probably wondering why I gave this place 4 stars rather than 5, well there are a couple of reasons. Firstly, at the advice of my friend who I dined with, I was better off not asking for water. Seems like the water here isn't very clean, not a good look for a restaurant. Secondly, seeing as I needed a cold beverage to wash down my meal, I asked for a coke which turned out to be literally half the price of my meal, also not a good look.

Great pricing, great food, and an overall great experience is what you can expect at New Woey Loey Goey Restaurant. At the end of the day, New Woey Loey Goey Restaurant to me was big hit....or rather an underground classic!
author: Judd H.

description: The people working are nice, but it was kind of confusing to get their attention and to order food. They also speak Cantonese really quickly, so most of my exchange with them will forever be a mystery. I ordered a mapo tofu to go, which was RIDICULOUSLY cheap for $4.65. I got a huge container of mapo tofu and rice, and it even came with a bonus soup. Not my kind of mapo tofu, though.
author: Melody L.

description:
This place is okayyyy, I wanted to like it! I really did since I was showing around my bf's family around. But the service was lacking cept the old chinese man has some character (maybe the owner?)  Had to keep asking for water refills and had to get up to get my own beverages. We ordered a family style dinner since we had 7 people, beer (pricey for Chinatown hole-in-the-wall at 7 bucks a bottle) drove our bill up over 20 bux a head. 

Food was alright, pretty large portions and tasted yums. 

Location is underground so it kept getting hella hot then hella cold (when they left the door open to air out) Pretty cramped so not for the faint-hearted.
author: Amy S.

description:
Relatively quick, tasty cheap eats. I always cringe when I see tourists (non chinese) eating Americanized chinese food, but I should calm down and realize that they are enjoying their meal as much as I enjoy mine. 


Hot Tip, the take out soup is boiling hot. Every time, without fail. Actually, all of it is hot. If i'm eating in my car at night (on a cold night) I have to put the food on a book to keep it from burning my lap. (laptops got nothing on their food). 

I also keep the soup in the plastic bag, and put it outside on the sidewalk while I eat in my car. It still takes quite some time for the soup to cool off in the night air. If you don't wanna burn your taste buds for the next few days, remember to let that food cool down!

Oh yeah, bathroom's atrocious. I tend to pay for the food, not the bathroom, so I have no issues here.
author: Tyrone B.

description: Dishonest :-(. Nice waiter, but when you get a $54.65 bill for two meals and ask for a itemized bill and it comes in Chinese it's discouraging. One meal was $8.50 and the crab was seasonal. And I understand "seasonal" variates, but at least if he would of given the price it would of been nice. Instead of just stating "tip is not included" when we asked about the prices. Food wasn't bad, but not worth about $35 for a deep fried crab legs that were obviously from a bag and not fresh.
author: Sergio S.

description:
First restaurant I've ever eaten at in SF's Chinatown J  Overall, the food was tasty, the portions large and the prices right.  I went with a friend and we ordered the Singaporean-style noodles, claypot w/ pork, oysters and tofu, pork chops, roast duck wonton soup, and fried squid.  The squid and claypot were great, the noodles good and the wonton soup and pork chops ok.  The wonton soup could have been better seasoned and the pork just seemed super fatty.  As in it was deep fried chunks of mostly breaded fat.  

Service here is very attentative and the space neat and well designed.  But I have had better, arguably more authentic Chinese food.  But my experience was good, so I'd give this place another try.

Also, lunch specials are only $4.50, so that's another thing to check out.  A bunch of people ordered specials and they were huge.
author: Timan G.

description: I work in the financial district and willing to walk all he way from work to here for the food.  Also, compared to the food around work, the prices here can't be beat.
author: Nicholas L.

description:
1.5 Stars

This was my childhood favorite restaurant since 1968.
Unfortunately,it has lost it's luster or original soul.
The decor has changed alittle for the better.They remodeled the entrance to the bathrooms.
Their prices are still very low.
They don't give you as much rice,now.
Before...they would put a bed of rice over the whole plate and put your entree on top. Now the put a large mound of rice on one side of the plate and the entree on the other side...some may said this difference is minor or petty but they had been doing it the other way for over 40 years and many other old school still serve" over rice" plates so to me it's a big deal.
I ordered Curry Beef Stew Chow Mein. The curry flavor was authentic but thin instead of thick and heavy. The "Now-Nom" was actually very tender. I did'nt like how the noodles came out.They were the thicker speghetti-like noodles instead of the skinnier/crispy mein. The chow mein was off.

The other thing that turned me off was that I picked this restaurant because it advertises with the Portsmouth Square Parking Garage that if you spend $20...you will get 2 hours free validation.Well... they raised the minimum to $30 but did'nt update the change online.

Bottomline- If you were a fan because you thought they have'nt changed in years...well, they have changed and it's worst now.
Not the same good old restaurant that it was for over 40 years.
author: Winston W.

description: Good but not great. Had the prawns in lobster sauce but it was more like small shrimp in a light black bean sauce. Still tasted good though. Servers were friendly and food was made fast.
author: Westwood D.

description:
My very picky grandmother told me about this place, so I had to try it.  

Mmmm, duck yee won ton.  Tasty tasty to the point where I sit at work with my chin in my hand and daydream a little bit about it.

The place is also pretty clean, though I haven't checked out the loo yet.  

Will be going back soon to check out some savory yummies.
author: Kimberly Q.

description: Me and my family wanted to visit china town and get something to eat. We didn't know a specific place and seeing that it all looks dingy and uninviting ( although there was some lady calling us into her restaurant. Literally inviting any non Asian/tourist looking people from across the street. [we didn't go there])we decided to go for the name that stuck out. We went down a few stairs and entered a run down dining room with worn out linoleum and dirty fish aquariums. On one side of the dining room was a long counter where old Chinese men drank tea under a muted tv playing an Asian soap opera . The tables were crammed together and all full of people (and not just Asian). So we figured it didn't only serve weird non Americanized food. The menu was non confusing and the server was a very nice and patient lady. Not only that but even though the place was packed, our order came out quickly and correctly. I didn't go crazy. Got the beef broccoli and a couple egg rolls. It was sooooo tasty! We were all very satisfied and would defiantly go back. I recommend this place to anyone who likes Chinese food but also for those who aren't sure about it. The whole staff was nice. Great experience!
author: Joseph K.

description: excellent food, i love this underground restaurant, they have good prices and free wifi.
author: Alejandro A.

description:
Woey Loy Goey......
I remember telling my brother to read the name out loud. We started laughing before he could finish saying "goey". Interesting name I must say when in Chinese it's pronounced "tong lok"...WEIRD! 

Anyways my grandparents love eating here. It's actually located underground, so its your average hole in the wall restaurant. Its small but don't get fooled by the size and decor, it can be very busy during dinner. Their "war choy" Chinese family style is okay. I've never been wowed any war choy since I'll pick my mommy's cooking any day any time. But oh man New Woey Loy Goey's dessert is yummy! Maybe I came on a lucky day but they had the taro with sago in coconut milk. YUM! I could have ate 2 bowls of that but I didn't. 

Want some cheap Chinese comfort food? Come to New Woey Loy Goey.
author: Tracy A.

description: The food deserves 3 stars but everything else doesn't. Good flavor and opens late in SF chinatown. The only problem is I found a hair on my plate and they didn't even take the dish out of the check! I don't think I would come back here.
author: Athena C.

description: CROOKS!  The food was good and inexpensive. The service....was atrocious, some of the worst I've had.  THEY WILL ADD THE TIP INTO YOUR BILL AND GARBLE IT WITH THE OTHER NUMBERS, ALL WORDS IN CHINESE, MOST NUMBERS ILLEGIBLE.
author: Karl S.

description:
Great place in the heart of Chinatown. Very uninviting walk down some steps to the basement restaurant seems to keep most tourists at bay. The night we were there, we were the only Caucasians in the place. Something I generally consider a good sign. 

They have some standards on the menu, and you can get what you expect in large portions at a very reasonable price. There are a lot of specialties written only in Chinese on a whiteboard on the wall. 

We just looked at what other customers were eating and asked for "that". We had an eggplant dish that was out of this world, and a steamed fish in black bean sauce (pretty expensive) that was just terrific. 

Service was very friendly (not so common in Chinatown) and helpful. 

The restaurant is very bare bones, with a bar counter where some lone diners were eating. If you feel a little adventurous when you're in the area, give this place a shot.
author: Frank D.

description: Bad restaurant with bad service, I had asked the boss and their co workers for soup and they bitch the crap out of me saying that they don't have enough soup for other. Even though that's true they shouldn't give me such a pain in the ass kind of attitude and should talk to me in a nice way. I was like damn...... I offered you guys bit you don't need to do it but just give me a explanation why and I'll forget about it. Do not come here. They are against racist.
author: Peter L.

description:
After walking all day (and I mean all day) around San Francisco, my hubby and I decided that we wanted Chinese Food in Chinatown. I powered up my trusty Yelp mobile on the celly to find someplace and good job Yelp, we found the New Woey. 
The place was very busy but we got a table in 10 minutes or so. Don't let the walk down to the cellar feel of the entrance disuade you. 
We ordered soup, walnut shrimp and the salt and pepper prawns.  I could skip the soup next time, but the entree dishes were good and prices are very reasonable. 
The location was great as well, in Central Chinatown. It was nice to walk around the cute little souvenier shops afterwards.
author: Annie C.

description:
The stairway down to the hole in the wall has a very good roast pork loin rice dish. The dish is very american with large thick slices of pork and it's very tasty along with their brown gravy to top it off.  I'm not sure if it's on their menu tho.

stinky tofu
author: StinkyTofu S.

description:
The best kind of restaurant find is one where you're just wandering around, are low blood sugar, and find a place that not only smells good, but where the food tastes just how you imagine it might. My friend and I had the following:

- potstickers (perfectly chewy and crunchy bottom - could have used a little more filling)
- sizzling rice soup (could have been a little hotter - temp wise)
- mu-shoo pork (the filling was outstanding - just like I remember it from my youth)
- beef with snow peas (not greasy, perfectly stir fried beef and crunchy peas)

This place is small. We were there on a Sunday night around 8ish, so not sure how crowded it gets on other nights or at lunch, but I will definitely bring friends and out of towners for delicious Chinese food.
author: Jenny R.

description: I actual liked this place, my 6 year son chose it. There are so many places to eat in Chinatown it is really hit and miss!  My son wanted tomato beef chow main and lemon chicken. I can't give a very good review of a restaurant and order something so gringo, but the dishes I did see looked really good. For instance I saw a whole fish dish that looked awesome and the vegetables looked really fresh and plentiful.  Service was very friendly and the price point was between $5 and $9 a dish for dinner. Lunch was about $2 cheaper a dish.
author: fred j.

description:
I'm Chinese, and I love going here to eat because their food is spot on and delicious.

Like all ethnic foods, it's the hole in the wall joints that make the best food.  This place is no exception.  It's dirty, and best of all in a basement.  How cool is that.  

(-1 star because of the lack of cleanliness... don't even think about going to the bathroom)
author: Derrick D.

description:
3 o'clock must be the magic hour for restaurants.  This is the time when lunch prices transform to dinner.

My friend and I were attracted to the long name of this place.  Walk down a few steps into the under belly of Chinatown to enter this place.

Place is comfy, not claustrophobic.

We ordered the Won Ton Soup in 'Supreme' broth.  Normally it's $3.95, but we ordered after 3p, so we paid a dollar more - no biggie.  It's a good size portion, the broth is pretty darn good too.  The won ton dumplings had lean meat inside along with some bok choy.  A good cheap place for a soup fix.
author: Cathy K.

description: This place is awesome! They say quality and cheap cannot come together... Wellthey do, in an authentic nice place! We were a bunch of international students n they helped us n were very helpful
author: Peter S.

description:
It was after the Chinese New Year parade and my bf and I were wandering around feeling a bit peckish.  As we walked down the street I pointed out the sign with the funny name to him and we had a laugh.  The idea of chop suey totally hit the spot, so down the flight of stairs we went.  

The place was definitely a little hole-in-the-wall.  It was really crowded for 9:30 on a Saturday night, but that was totally understandable because of the parade.  We had to wait a while for a table, but there was no way we were leaving without our chop suey.

Our waiter was kinda a spaz in a funny way.  We ordered BBQ pork chop suey and egg foo young.  At that moment, it seemed like it was the best American Chinese food I'd ever tasted.  It didn't just hit the spot, it sucker-punched it in the face, and I was left licking what was left of the plate.  I think their secret was in the brown sauce and I spent the greater part of last week trying to make my own imitations.

Their restroom gave me horrors though.
author: Monica W.

description: Recently a book came out about how to find a restaurant with really good food.  It's not the cloth napkins, it's not the hipster waitstaff, it's not a "scene"  with beautiful people getting drunk before the food arrives, it's not the glassware or the silverware.  It's all about the food and how much the people in the kitchen care about what goes out into the dining room.  This restaurant cares.  I've never had a bad meal here, not even a so-so meal.  Always delicious in the way maybe only a Chinese person who grew up with this stuff would appreciate.  The people who eat here come to eat good food.  Not to impress anybody.  Not to have a "life changing" experience.  If you want to have an outstanding Chinese meal for a more than reasonable price come here.  If you want to have a "restaurant experience" and be fawned over like the VIP you think you are, don't.  The lunch plate of sliced lotus root with pork is amazing, so many levels of texture and taste.  All for less than $5 with tax.  This is a big tip place, because it's worth much more.  Bring your out of town relatives, order the family dinner for 10 and go home happy that you made the right choice.
author: Rona M.

description: party of 5 ate there on Saturday, Jan 2. around 330pm.  It was not crowded.  All the food we got was hot and delicious.  Portions were good.  The environment was plain and simple, but clean and neat.  Wait staff were fine.  I would definitely go back or refer my friends to this place.
author: Sue B.

description: Average tastes. Genuinely cheap prices. Surprisingly empty for dinner. Not a place to go out of your way to visit, but not a place to avoid. There you go! Brevity.
author: Peter B.

description:
I read about this place on Yelp. It was rainy yesterday when we decided to visit Chinatown, and I had remembered that I had read about this place, so we ducked in to check it out. The restaurant is in a basement just as other reviewers had described, but the place was not dirty or dingy at all! (Much to my surprise) Sure the bathroom may have been, but that is how Chinatown is, what can one expect? Of course there was the Madarin-only menu with better prices, but my friend and I knew what we wanted as soon as we walked in. We ordered the Beef with Tender Greens on Rice (this is a lunch special, but you can have it for dinner for just $1 more).  He also wanted a beer, but I warned him that since there were no prices for beverages, that would would be charged a pretty penny for a tasteless Tsingtao beer; We stuck with the hot tea. The waitress was friendly and comical. The restaurant had about 4 other groups dining (only one of which included a caucasian group he others were Chinese). There were the seedy single men at the bar, but the kept to themselves, so we were not bothered. The meal came fast and STEAMING HOT! also came the check, which I found a bit strange because the server did not ask if we would like dessert...
I enjoyed the beef. It was tender and the sauce had a nice bite to it. My friend felt that the Bok Choy was too hard to eat and piled most of it on my plate, but I found it to be perfectly cooked. Overall this place gets three stars because I did notice that a group of flies liked to hover in one corner of the restaurant.... weird. The food was pretty good quality for being so cheap. We paid a total of $6.75 for the entire meal (one order was enough for us both) I would still say to just go to King Lee's off of Fillmore or your favorite place because this place is super hard to find unless you know where you are going.
author: Antoinette C.

description: Bought take out seafood chow mein here.  It was tasty without being greasy and salty.  Definitely cheap too!
author: Wendy H.

description: There aren't very many good places to eat in Chinatown anymore, but this place is the exception. They have tasty food at very affordable prices. It's not a hole-in-the-wall, more like a hole-in-the-ground.
author: Sara K.

description: This has to be one of the cheapest lunch places around. The food is good and the place is almost hidden as you have to go to the basement. One star is missing for ventilation and lighting.
author: S M.

description:
had dinner with my father and we ordered Goat in clay pot, snails , beef with bok choy, pot of white rice, soup of the day, pot of hot tea.

They have fresh live seafood in tanks right next to the dining area for viewing.  One of my favorites is the catfish with black bean sauce.

I think the food here is excellent! Ive been here many times and it's always good.

nice hole in the wall thats been in business for many years, I like the downstairs / underground design it's very unique.
author: Mr Bolo B.

description:
So I was in San Franxcsco with a bunch of Boy Scouts and we were looking for a cheap place to eat in Chinatown because teenagers don't have a lot of money to spend.  We decided to eat at New Woey Loy Goey Restaurant.

We were seated in a corner of the restaurant, which was smart, because these boys have a tendency to get loud.  Five of us shared the Szechwan dinner for five.  Now I have seen these boys pack away more than 100 shrimp at the Red Lobster, so I was surprised when we ended up with leftovers.  

The hot and sour soup was outstanding (could it have tasted extra good because it was 45 degrees outside?  All of the dishes were pretty solid, but they were a bit skimpy with the scallops.  I would definitely recommend this place for cheap Chinese food.
author: Jeffrey H.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in Chinatown or as the kids call it now "Chi-town".  Might be a little intimidating to...uh...non-chinese people or...how do I say this... people who don't know what's up.

Very good food here and fast service.  Bring cash though as there credit machine goes down a lot or they just don't take cause of fees.

Great place for a party of five or six.  Keep in mind this is famliy style, so don't go ordering single dishes for yourself.

I recommend getting....

Bean Cake combination in pot  and Peking Pork Spareribs.
author: Buddy R.

description: Came here with family and it was good.The place was a hole, kinda scary like a rat might fly out since it's in a basement in Chinatown! Had some steamed egg dish with different eggs in the middle of it, real good! Meat patty was good, fish with blackbean sauce, good, shrimp chowmein was good and we had some other stuff. The food was good traditional Chinese food. I'm happy I didn't see the cleanliness rating until I left the place, it was like a 72! Ewww happy I didn't see the nasty parts
author: Karen T.

description:
I lOOOOOVE this place! Cheap but great food! I recommend Clay Pot, especially Oyster and Polk one and 
Lamb stew. Chinese green with garlic is also nice. I wish I was live in the next door....
author: Takako O.

description:
A fantastic culinary experience.  I went a few times with an adventurous friend and got the family dinner off the Chinese menu not entirely knowing what we were getting into.  The mystery soup, Mustard Greens with garlic, Ginger Chicken, Sweet and Sour Pork Chops, Steamed Pork and Duck feet and Salt and Pepper Shrimp - the only thing I wasn't absolutely crazy about was the soup. 

I had to talk the waiter into letting me order it the second time.  I think this speaks to the American condition of going into an ethnic restaurant and expecting the Americanized (PFChangs) version to show up - and then of course complaining when it does.

The seasoning in all these dishes was superb (I'm drooling about those chops).  A word of caution - those things that look like water chestnuts in the ginger chicken are not - they are ginger.  Send your picky friends to Changs and come here ...
author: Brian K.

description: I've been here several times and always leave satisfied. Rather plain looking place but with good looking waiting staff, they are dressed  in black slacks, white shirt and a black vest. A family oriented kind of place. Great prices and tastefully prepared dishes. The only problem I encountered was that the beer was not cold enough and was not able to pay with my credit card since the cashier was  away for 30 minutes. Otherwise, next time you are in the area give the place a try.
author: Hum V.

description: I came here for lunch years ago and it felt darker and dingy-er  but this time we went for dinner and it was pretty crowded and well lit.  We got a table pretty quickly and ordered shrimp with black bean sauce (good amount of shrimp but I like my clams with black bean sauce better), spicy salt squid (yummy), and eggplant hot pot (yummy).  All the dishes were pretty tasty and good portions for around $8 or less.  The rice wasn't as well cooked.  When the bill came, there were $3 extra added to the bill, I don't know what that was for (tea maybe?) since I can't read Chinese.  I didn't question it since it wasn't a big deal and the meal was good.  I did notice though that the non-Asian diners got after-dinner fortune cookies while we didn't get anything.  Usually, after dinner in a Chinese restaurant, you get at least some orange slices.
author: Annie C.

description:
I went in on Christmas night for dinner with a few friends and noticed we were the only non-Chinese in the place, which is usually a good sign in an ethnic restaurant.  When we went to order, we tried to order a family style dish that had nothing written in English, hoping that we would get some very authentic food, but the waiter insisted that we didn't get it for fear that we wouldn't like it.  I am a very adventurous eater and really wanted to try it but he convinced us all so we shied away.  
We ended up ordering a quite a few other dishes including roasted duck, dungeness crab, braised quail and some cabbage and pork clay pot.  Everything was good, but I couldn't help but think we got the "gringo" versions of these authentic Chinese dishes.  My "braised" quail and the "sauteed" crab both came out deep-fried.   Just looking around, nobody had anything that looked like what we had, but that could just be because they got the meals written in Mandarin.  Anyway, I really did like this food and will be coming back with my Chinese speaking friend sometime.
author: Dan L.

description:
I used to go to SF Chinatown once a week on weekends to buy magazines and check out the import CD and DVD shops. I remember I came down here once (literally basement level) and just got a noodle dish/item, but don't recall anything else after that.

First of all, I clicked on the yelp photo, and the Chinese name/characters is pronounced Tong Lok. How the $#@XYZ did it become New Woey Loy Goey? And they seem to be proud of their Chop Suey too. Perhaps this place does offer the moo shoo poo poo chop soo goo goo broo hoo hoo doo doo stuff, but no thanks, I'll just stick with the classics. 

Non Cantonese speakers are going to have so much fun with the pronounciation. Woey probably is pronounced closer Wui, and not wooo-eee, and Goey is certainly not gooey/goo-weee which can be very visually unappetizing.

This place certainly has interesting and decent stir fry rice plates, noodles, and maybe noodle soups, also at good value, but it is definitely not refined like in Hong Kong, although they are similar to that old Hong Kong flavor in the usage of MSG to some extent (and in cases here probably more heavily so). Perhaps their food is somewhat simliar to Hong Kong stir fry/rice/noodle plates in the 60s/70s or even the 50s, in another perspective. Again we go back to old Chinatown, old receipes that eventually revolved to localized tastes (at times bigger portions), generation after generation with some whitewashing down here and there, and maybe additions to the menu for the moo shoo doo doo fans. Xth gen Chinese Americans will certainly love it here or have fond memories coming to places like here as kids, and low gen / homesickers like quite a few of us, will probably find a bit of that special old country flavor here.

Sadly the skankiness of Chinatown is part of the dining experience. Suck it up, and eat it up, and don't think of anything else but the food.
A little white pepper on the rice plates or stir fried noodle plates go a long way.
author: Ken K.

description:
This little spot that is one notch above hole-in-the-wall status has become one of my all time favorites in Chinatown. It passes all my criteria:

Great food + large portions + cheap prices = 5 star rating

I have not yet ordered a dish that I did not like.
author: John C.

description:
This is definitely a little secret spot in Chinatown.  It gets busy every night here, and can result in some serious waiting time.  Hands down they have the best snails in Chinatown!  Usually we asked them what are veggies of the day, and the one my dad picked turned out to be $14! $14 for a plate of veggies!?!?! absolutely outrageous!  So next time before you get suckered into ordering something they recommend, please double check the price.  Their stuff peppers+eggplants+tofu dish is great.  My personal favorite (although not exactly sure what it's called) is this steamed duck feet cake or something.  Sounds gross, but definitely tastes uber good.  

They give complimentary soup, rice, and dessert of the day.  Definitely one of the more expensive places to eat dinner, but I like the home feel of this restaurant.  It's usually packed with people, and it's nice and rowdy, just the way i like it.
author: Emily L.

description: This restaurant ripped me by selling me an ice tea for $3.25.their food is decent but you may feel a lil suffocated as it's located in the basement. be careful to ask for explaining the bill details as they knowingly overcharge foreigners
author: Yelp F.

description: This is a total hole in the wall and was completely full of Chinese people with the exception of my wife and I. The food was great and the price of our meals was insanely inexpensive. We ordered tea, I got mongolian beef and she ordered some sort of beef with rice dish. The bill was ten dollars and eighty cents. We will definitely return here again.
author: American E.

description: I would never have walked into this restaurant on my own.  This restaurant is not street level, you have to walk down 10 steps or more to get in.  The first time I ate here was with my Mother in Law and the family, she knows the staff, so she ordered all the good dishes.  This restaurant is very affordable and tasty! I took my mother here also, and she loved it!  Its another hole in the wall chinese restaurant for you nothing fancy, just your typical chinatown chinese restaurant!  Every time i've been there, it's always been more than 6 tables of guests...
author: Rachel R.

description: One of those underground places in Chinatown, but it wasn't too low.  A nice breeze blowing in from the outside and natural light made you feel like you were at street level.  Got the Kung Pao Chicken rice plate and I thought it was good.  Chicken quality was fine, good flavor, nice assortment of vegetables.  I left feeling full and satisfied, but it wasn't a place I would go back to over another for Kung Pao.  Still, I'd definately go back to try some other dishes and it was super cheap ($4.60).  Meal included the usual mystery soup with a fat-covered bone from some part of a cow floating in it, I presume for flavor.  It wasn't bad.  Tea was strong and included.  No fortune cookie.  Place was fairly packed around 12:15 with locals so it must be highly regarded.  There's a counter for the old single dishelved males dining alone to sit at, but I chose a table so I could spread out my newspaper.
author: Marc S.

description: As a new person in town, I was already nervous when I had to climb down a flight of stairs to enter the restaurant.  To my surprise, I found a restaurant full of people!  With a party of six, we had to wait for our table, but their service was so fast once we entered!  We were seated once a new table opened.  My dad ordered several vegetable/meat combination dishes, but they turned out oily (duh).  I did like the noodle soup though!  The dumplings were light in terms of fat and even the broth was clear of fat!  The noodles were soft too!  We also mentioned to the waitress that  we were in a rush, and they were able to get the dishes ready ASAP.  Though most Chinese restaurants and their respective restrooms are known for being ghetto and dirty, I liked the decor of the restaurant!  It's unique; it has a "bar" and a restroom that leads you into a narrow hallway with one stall (+ only one person can fit in)!  I was expecting a painful experience, but it turned out pleasant!
author: Janey Y.

description: I had the shrimp fried rice and a bowl of won ton soup with bok choy. Yummy!! It was around 8 bucks and I left feeling quite full. The green lino floor is definitely from the 60's. Don't let that get in the way of the good food. The restaurant was full of Chinese people and you know that means the food is good.
author: Rafael L.

description:
Um, it's actually Loy, not Loey.

This is my new favorite restaurant.
I am in love with "Spicy Egg Plant in Pot." Delicious!
